description: I've heard one or two rave reviews about Ali Baba's, as one of those places that are nondescript and unknown but loved-by-locals (thinking of Falafel's Drive-in on Stevens Creek in San Jose as a comparison). However I wasn't too impressed. Inside, it's shabby and a little grungy, and my lamb shwerma plate was overcooked and very dry, with a little too much gristle. The hummus was very good though.
author: Stephen S.

description:
I am on a quest to find the perfect falafel. Ali Baba's comes close and is one of the best I have had.

Awesomeness:
-Lots of food
-Spicy sauce that is actually spicy
-Crispy falafel that is soft on the inside and well spiced
-Great Tahini sauce
-the red onions are a good touch, so is the parsley
-The lavash is nice and crispy since they grill it
-Good hummus
-Fast
-Drunk friendly

Not so Awesomeness:
-It was warm from the grill for a few minutes but it was not warm throughout. By the time i got into my falafeley groove, it was cold.
-The fries and eggplant inside seemed to have been sitting around awhile, not quite the best texture. 

I have the feeling that if everything was fresh and hot, this would be in the top 2 or 3 falafel sandwiches in my life. I am going to have to try it again before I have a few drinks and when everything is fresh and hot. I have high hopes about it. Until then, I will be dreaming about Falafels, mmmmm.
author: Peter V.

description:
Went here because it is right down the street from my favorite bar and I was craving hummus.  When you walk in there is a set up kind of like at burrito spots.  Food in metal dishes, covered and warming.  I got the fried eggplant, fried potatoes, hummus, and the chicken kabobs.  Everything was wonderful except the staff kind of seemed like they didn't want us there and the kabobs, which they said would take 10-20 minutes took 30.  Great food, but by the time they brought the main dish I had them wrap it up because we were going to be late.  

The best part of the whole thing is the tent they have in the dining room.  A beautiful red canopy tent with a low round table with pillows all around it.  It was quaint, cute, and totally unexpected.  It's the only reason I am going to back here. The food is fine, but made so much better when actually in your own secret cave!
author: Meara G.

description:
I got the beef shawarma when I was starving, and even then I had a hard time enjoying it. They tried to substitute quality and taste with ridiculous amounts of salt. The beef was also extremely dry, and fairly fatty.

Overall, I was not impressed with the food at all. The service was also slow. Probably won't return any time soon.
author: Armon D.

description: IMO they make one of the best falafels and super falafels. It is always very fresh and nicely toasted the hot sauce is great too. and for about $7 it is a very cheap lunch.
author: Michael W.

description: I didn't go for the atmosphere- I went for the food. Sizable portions that are affordable. The eggplant was so good!
author: Alex O.

description:
On a recent visit to the bay, had to hit our favorite spots on Valencia.  Ali Baba's Cave was our first stop. It had been 2 1/2 years and the only thing different was the dacor (new paint, new table tops and chairs I think), very bright and clean. The food was as good as ever. How they manage to make fluffy humus I dont know, but so tasty. We had the falafel combo and dolmas. The falafels were huge with nice crunchy crust cook to order. We ate and ate it all.  The cost was very reasonable and the portions large. 

I stopped and spoke with the gentleman who served us, The owner I think .  I wanted to know where he's from. Every middle eastern place has a different story, our favorite in Portland is from Lebanon. Anyway he's from Egypt. Given recent events there I congratulated him on the changes in his country. He was cauciously exuberent. "we will get there, not yet, but I am certain it's is coming soon".  I could sense a strong connection with his homeland and it's struggles, yet another reason to support his restaurant.
author: Julie H.

description:
I ate something weird here. I forget what it was. And a diet coke. That I do
remember.

I guess I partied in the cave nearly 10 years ago, and don't remember it being as dank as it is now. We were drunk, and dot commers roamed freely thru the mission. I wasn't one of them. They're gone and Im still here.
author: Henry Y.

description: Awesome Shawerma, tabbouleh fresh and not overwhelming with parsley.   Will gladly go again.
author: Adrian E.

description:
On my walk home from Medjool we were starving, it was 10pm and most places in the Mission were closed. A shwarma sounded like a good idea. This was my first time in Ali Baba AND my last.. 

Ewww the worst shwarma ever.. YUCK! I had mine with lamb, they also offer chicken.. There were HUGE pieces of fat in it.. Gross, I can't come back here ever again. 

Truly Med is my fav.. I find it hard to venture out when they just get it soo right.
author: Monica S.

description: Mmmmm...yum. My friend cut me a chunk of her falafel sando and wowza. So GOOD! She treated me to a baklava as well which was also good. Maybe could've been a bit moister. Service was very friendly as well. Now I know why that place is so popular!
author: Nicole O.

description: Friend of mine was still hungry after dinner at OSHA thai down the street, so we stopped by here for a chicken plate with eggplant and side salad. The staff was very helpful
author: David D.

description:
Not only was this incredibly flavorful and plentiful, but the next day my scale, which does percentages, was very happy. Nothing was soggy with oil or overly salty like many Med/Middle Eastern places. There are lots of options, not just the standard ME mall fare. We had grilled sandwiches rolled in Lavash the way that Lavash bread NEVER IS and should always be--like the most delicate part of a dutch crunch maybe. Filled with crushed sesame-filled falafel, fried eggplant, a tomato mixture, french fries (which I skipped), etc. Another friend had a combo plate and was entirely happy. The sandwiches and plates are big enough for a large man's appetite and if you are a smaller eater, you can take half home, and they heat up nicely on a pan or in a microwave.
this is also a pretty good place to park during the day if you hit a side street off Valencia.
This doesn't come up on a search of Middle Eastern food, it's listed as Mediterranean but is Middle Eastern/Israeli type food.
author: czenzi o.

description: I usually ate at the Lower Haight Street location.  The Valencia location has more room.  Great Felafel, Hummus and Babaganoush. Good prices, especially for San Francisco.
author: S E.

description:
I can't recall eating a worse meal in the city of SF. Ali Baba and his thieves took $10.79 off me -- don't let him do the same to you.

I wandered out of Amnesia looking for something to eat when I came upon Ali Baba's, which sounded good. I ordered a lamb kebab, but the lady behind the counter looked at me like I was crazy and told me that would take 20 minutes to cook. So I ordered a lamb shwarma instead.

Being tipsy and hungry I dug in. It was pretty awful right away. Especially the lamb, which was terribly over-salted and almost as charred as it could possibly be. It was almost inedible. As my stomach taught me soon afterward, in fact it actually was inedible -- a lesson I learned the hard way. My friend told me she got sick after eating here too -- I hope the city shuts it down.
author: Adam Z.

description:
I ordered a party platter here. It was sort of expensive and had too much of the same thing. They looked kind of annoyed when I ordered.
The place is gross looking.
The falafel isn't awesome. This is San Francisco, and things should be awesome.
author: Andrew K.

description:
Hummus was great but the lamb shawarma meat was tough and fatty. I wanted the shish kabob, but they said it was going to take 20 minutes. I wish I would have waited.

Tables were not clean.
author: Courtney D.

description:
Palmer and I walked in 4 sangria's in deep Friday night.

"Are they seriously putting french fries in the falafel?"

"Yes."

"Are you serious?"

"Yes.  Say no onion.  Well, I'm going to say no onion.  I don't want to die alone."

"OMG FRENCH FRIES IN THE FALAFEL?!"

"Yes. Remember!  No onion!"

I don't know what's wrong with the Ali Baba's in the lower haight but this one by far definitely cures the falafel addiction that hits every 2 months.
author: Jen I.

description:
There's a reason why its a cave. When you head to the tables in the back, there's a den with pillows and a table with short legs. It looks comfy ...and dirty.

The food is good and they give u a lot for what u pay for. I got the lamb sherma sandwich with everything. Some of the stuff they put inside are hummus, fries, hot sauce. Word of advice: choose the correct side to start from. Mine was starting to break apart after the first bite.
author: Joseph B.

description:
BEST FALAFEL IN THE MISHHHHHHHHHHHHHH!
enough said.
this is deff one of my intense cravings in life.
looove.

but then again, i eat my falafel without the chili sauce..too much to handle on such unpretentious wrap. hahhaha
author: Marc K.

description: Best falafel every had outside of the Middle East of Dearborn, Michigan.  Fresh, Flavorful,  not "Bready" awesome portion and service with passion for the food made.  Michigan does not have falafel of this tasting magnitude.
author: Vim P.

description:
There are better places to get everything that is offered here.
Boring hummus. 
Bland sides.
Overly spicy and pricey shawarma.

Do not want.
author: Addyline L.

description:
3.5 stars. 

I was definitely impressed. Came here for lunch today w/moms. Had a falafel and it was quite tasty. My moms dish, not quite as good- the lamb was not great. 

But, still. Didn't have high expectations, but they were surpassed. Will I be back? A definite maybe!

Totally affordable- good spot for lunch in the mish or if you need to order cheap food for a big group.
author: Art A.

description: Good, not great. Chicken was dry, hot sauce was hot! Service was standard and the little grotto/casbah was cool...
author: John R.

description: I absolutely love this place. Again, i go to one of the two locations every time i'm up in the area. this place never lets me down, sober or drunk. food is fantastic and this place is always inviting. the only thing that i didnt like this time around was the ohzi al sham, the vegetarian version was dry and didnt really have much taste to it. LAMB  SHAWERMA for the win!!!
author: John N.

description:
Excellent deal under $10 to share a big Shwarma. 

Big fan of the hot sauce. Hummus and falafel are cooked ethnically correct. 

Don't get eggplants in the wrap, the skins doesn't go well with it. 

Cheap. Fast. Nourishing.
author: Jack C.

description:
[Reviewed by Drew]

Great for a cheap lunch! The Maza Combination Plate is by far the best deal on the menu. The Shawermas are ginormous, but watch out for the leaking sauces (we tend to put a lot of cucumber yogurt sauce in it).

Drew is a regular here. It's on the corner of Valencia and 19th, so it's within walking distance if you decide to forgo the five million tacquerias on Mission.

The reason it's not a four-star place is the limited menu.While it has the Mediterranean staples like hummus or baba ghanoush, the gyro plates aren't as comprehensive as some other places in the city.

Also, the portions are inconsistent. On most days, the portions are adequate, but on occasion, we get 3/4 of the normal portions. What's up with that?

All in all, Ali Baba's is one of the few Mediterranean places in the Mission, so that's why we keep coming back (we are currently the Duke and Foursquare mayor of this place). However, if they could expand their menu a bit and work on their portions, they could become the next hidden gem in the area.
author: Kel S.

description:
delish. used to go here after a night at the Lex. Great vegetarian falafel. Loved that they were open late during Ramadan. 


Only Maoz gets the full 5 stars b/c of an amazing falafel experience.  Sorry.
author: Abi W.

description:
Many things about Ali Baba's cave are great, and I can't deny that some were a factor in choosing where in the mission to move to. The clear star of this place, as with most mediterranean places in the city, is the shawerma, but this place has a few unique ingredients.

First, fried eggplant. If you haven't had it before, it may be a bit different, but it's quite savory and adds a nice texture. They also put hummus, quality hummus, that doesn't overpower the dish. French fries are next on the unconventional ingredients list, and while they aren't quite the type you'd eat on their own, they do add to the overall heartiness of the wrap. They also add a mediterranean salad with tomatoes, cucumber, and some kind of yogurt sauce, which lightens up the other heavy ingredients nicely (including the spicy sauce, which I highly recommend!).

I didn't mention the meat since, frankly, it's not the superstar of the bunch. Try asking for it from the spit, since unrequested they tend to use pre-sliced meat kept in a metal container that tends to be on the chewy side. 

Or just go for the hummus and pita! It's reason (and meal) enough to make the visit worthwhile.
author: Jared J.

description:
The veggie shawarma is pure bliss. It's hugemongous and every bite is magical. There's falafel, hummus, tomato concoction, hot sauce, potatoes, eggplant - probably more  I'm leaving out. 

Only wish I lived closer to this place.
author: Chili B.

description: Came here to grab a quick bite. Its a pretty small place and you order up front and there are tables you can sit at at the back of the restaurant. I ordered the shwarma wrap and it came with fried potatoes (like fries?), hummus, a hot sauce, etc., It was wrapped up and then grilled until it was crispy. When it was fresh it was super yummy cuz the wrapping was all crispy and the hot sauce made it so good, I wish he wouldve put so much more in it though. I kinda wish there was something else in this because the potato and meat seemed so heavy and kinda like mushed together. I wish there were more distinct flavors like maybe add some vegetables or more sauce.  I should've tried the falafel one!! I only was able to finish about 2/3 of the wrap in one sitting and i'd say it was about $9? Overall it was decent but I'm not sure if i'd return.
author: Isabella L.

description:
consistently dirty and disorganized, but if you can live with that, then it's ok
they don't even have paper menus for you to take home
not enough mediterranean togo style places around, but there are some
this is physically the closest to mi casa
the owners seemed to have quit caring about this restaurant and it shows
author: G K.

description:
My review has disappeared. I will review it one more time. This place has RATS!!!!!  Real rats, they are running around the restaurant. A lot of them!

My friends visited me from San Diego, and I recommended this place. We all got something to eat, and decided to wait for out food.  When we got our food and start eating, I noticed that my husband's facial expression is way not normal and he is staring somewhere in front of him... I looked in the same direction and there were at least 5 rats, 2 of them were running towards us.  It is disgusting...

Food is OK... but I lost my appetite after seeing so many rats in one place, not in a cage.

If you like to eat and watch rats... then come over to Alibaba's, but I would never even come close to this place
author: Dasha T.

description:
My wonderfully handsome food floozy accomplice (my man) brought me to Ali Baba's Cave one night long ago.  Back then, I had not self-proclaimed myself a food floozy yet, because I didn't know much about shawarmas or falafels.  We ordered the lamb and beef shawarmas, with all the fixings, with extra hot sauce.  I love their hot sauce, not because it is particular spicy (which it definitely is), but because it is very flavorful.  It brings the deliciousness of the shawarma together. 

Being another one of my favorite hole in the walls!  Only wish, would be to have them remodel the interior.  It would be a great place to just hang out. 

 EAT ON!
author: Rachel B.

description:
Ali Baba's felafel has it's fanboys and fangirls as well as it's detractors, I'd say it's average-to-good.   Best you ever tasted?  Nah.  Cheap? Not really.  Big...? Uh huh!

The felafel is very large, more than enough to fill you up with some left to share so I recommend you request no potatoes as it doesn't need the filler.  Also recommend no eggplant if you hate eggplant (duh :P) else you'll be unpleasantly surprised.

The balls are usually crispy outside, chewy inside, but not very spicy.  What is spicy is their harissa sauce, so if your tummy can't handle spicy foods very well or /if you are drunk/ you want to ask for no spicy.  The bread is lavash -- which they grill till flakey, not pita. They paint the inside with hummus, tabouleh and their own version of tzatziki.  Their tabouleh is tasty but it perhaps adds a little too much parsley?  This wouldn't be a problem if they used more lemon juice in the tabouleh to balance it but alas, you can't even taste the lemon which is a total fail IMO.  Felafel needs to have a bright flavor apart from green herbs, a sour, some zing!  But, the lack of lemon flavor is nothing different from most felafels in SF save for Haig's. /sigh

The alcove they call the cave is cute and a fun place to sit with friends.  

The shawermas are good but if you can make yourself stumble over to Mission and up another 8 block or so to Old Jerusalem, you can get better shawerma.
author: Ben S.

description:
Their chicken shawerma wrap is delicious.  They get the seasoning perfect imho.  I read that it was too spicy for someone else.  I disagree.  In fact, my girlfriend and I tend to end up fiending for more hot sauce.  Their falafel wrap left something to be desired.

Get here when no one else is around and grab the comfy cave all for yourself.
author: Pickles T.

description: ABC is great -- the value is unbeatable.  I hit it up at least once a week on my way home from work.   I usually get the veggie combo plate, and they'll allow you to sub the salad for grape leaves -- do it, yum.  The staff is friendly and the wait time is minimal.
author: J D.

description: One word that can describe the food here is...DRY! The flatbread is dry. The meat is dry. The falafels are dry. The hummus is dry and pasty.  Even the tabouleh was dry!  I have to say the shawerma did look the part, but it was deceiving!  With only 2 people working, service was great though. Sorry, but sometimes service just isn't enough for me to return.
author: Gina S.

description: food was actually pretty good considering it's somewhat of a level above a hole-in-a-wall mediterranean joint. i ordered the kebab combination platter and the meat was not too dry. portions are pretty sizable for the price. interiors could use some sprucing/renovating/better-newer furniture tho as it didnt seem that "clean" looking to me. lighting can be dimmed down a bit to make it more cozier. service was just ok. cashier/waitress was chit-chatting a lot to a customer while i stood in front of her waiting for her to stop yapping so i can ask her for a glass of water. i'd give it 3.5 stars if only yelp will allow 1/2 stars!! hear me, yelp??
author: p f.

description:
Huge portions, inexpensively priced and DELISH  -  the BEST combination.

Bring a friend and pick 2 things and share!

Definitely try the lamb.
author: Mike J.

description:
I wish I could give two separate reviews for this place.

On the one hand:
Ali Baba's Cave provides quick service with a smile and their falafel wraps are delicious!! I love that you can put fries and eggplant into a falafel wrap because it takes this creation to a whole new level.
The inside is pretty cute and clean, and I've never had an issue finding a seat.

On the other hand:
My body hates this place! The first time I went here, I had to rush home after I was done eating so I could spend some quality time with my toilet. I then vowed to never eat here again because I felt so shitty, but since their wraps are so delicious, I started having cravings and had to give in. So I ate here again and alas, my body was not happy with me.

Final verdict: Now I know that I must plan accordingly on when to eat here, which is going to be very rarely because I don't like feeling sick.

I'll stick to La Med for falafel that won't kill my insides.
author: Amanda M.

description:
Sorry, Truly Mediterranean, I'm a convert to Ali Baba's Cave.  Their chicken shwarma was better than yours and it was spicier with a fuller flavor.  More importantly, it didn't have to be Tuesday or Thursday or whenever the hell it is you decide to have Chicken Shwarma.  For flavor and a table you can sit at. [and they have that great seating area on the floor but it's always taken up by hooka loungers.  I don't even think you can hoo-ooka in their.  Whatever.  My food was screaming and I will be back to taste the lamb.  

Important note:  when they say spicy, they mean that shit!  phew!
author: Jonathan B.

description:
I had to have  a kebab so when I noticed this place I just walked in.
Yes they had a  lamb kebab  so I ordered to go. Kebab was good (little gristle is no big deal ) but the quality of the wrap was disappointing : the whole thing fell apart after 2 bites and  I  was covered with juice and ingredients ...I will give them another try , this time eating at the table and maybe ordering some different dishes.
author: Dupa B.

description:
While studying abroad in Amsterdam, shwarmas became my second favorite food while going out, coming only second to frites with some awesome sauce. Several months after coming back home from my stay, my sister asks if I wanted a shwarma. Apparently, she found this place while I was studying abroad and couldn't get enough of it. So I got a lamb shwarma and it just brought back all those great memories of hanging out with my friends abroad... then again, so do the Dutch caramel wafers from Starbucks and Trader Joe's.

After moving out of my parents' house, I had only had one or two shwarmas, but not from here. A couple of months ago, I needed to get out of the apartment, so I called up my sister and I hung out in the Mission with her. Long story short, we came here because for some reason, I wanted a shwarma. Out of all the choices I had on Mission and Valencia, I'm glad I came here. 

The lamb shwarma was just really good. The people making it were pretty cool as well. I had never ate here since we always had take out before. The place looks like a hole-in-the-wall, but luckily, I love these places. It wasn't crowded with people and I didn't see any bugs crawling around.

So, I've never been to Old Jerusalem and I haven't had their falafel yet, so I can't compare Ali Baba's to the other place, or any other in the City. It's not as good as the restaurants I've been to in Amsterdam, but that could just be nostalgia talking. Personally, I really like this place and if I ever come back to the Mission, this is definitely a top option.
author: Chris S.

description:
I got the vegetarian ohzi, which was very boring - just a large serving of  rice with a bland crust around it.  

Two friends got deluxe falafels, which were huge, decent tasting and reasonably priced.  Better and cheaper than Zaytoon IMHO.

The service was a little surly and disorganized - definitely second the other posters here.  The lavash for my friend's shwarma broke while the woman was making it but she just wrapped it up anyway, so it kind of fell apart while he was eating it.

I might go there again and get a takeout falafel, but I'd try Truly Mediterranean first.
author: Alex M.

description: Love this joint, always hits the spot when have a ridiculous appetite. I always get the chicken shawerma with no potatoes so its not to dry and a extra lil side of tahini. You can easily make it your lunch and dinner or share with the homie. If your a veggie fan order the falafel platter and get extra tahini. best $8 spent ever! Oh and they have this cool little intimate cave (seating area) but its usually taken.
author: Omar K.

description:
My friend raves about their schwarma's.

My thoughts, however, differ.

Large lamb schawerma for the price. Red sauce was perfect like fire. But! Lamb was lacking in flavor. The entire wrap was kinda dry. It all fell apart in 3 bites.  =/

Not cool.
author: Deanna T.

description:
I enjoyed my experiences with the food & environment here.

The cool little partially enclosed majestic looking seating area towards the back was neat. 

I totally loved their falafel sandwich (this is the only thing I've ever had from them---which goes to show you it was good because I came back). The sanwiches are also HUGE!

Also a pretty nice menu selection and overall pleasant interior. Decent service.

If the prices were any higher I'd have knocked off a star but... they don't exceed any limits in my book.... yet. 5 stars for me not being able to think of a reason to give 'em less!
author: Kai S.

description: This place has the look of a classic Yelp 4.5 star restaurant: it's kind of dirty, run by foreigners, and is in the Mission district.  What's most important, though, is the food, and that's where Ali Baba's Cave disappoints. The chicken shawarma wrap I ordered was heated so much, that the wrapping cracked and the whole thing fell apart into my plate :(. When I order a wrap I don't want to have to use a fork, goddammit.
author: David H.

description:
It has been awhile since I had good Falafel. I have been curious about this place for awhile. It was a great surprise. We ate under $10 and walked out full. 
We had super falafel and dolmas. Delicious. I liked how the eggplant complimented the falafel but the roll could of used more sauce. Next time I will ask for more on the side...
All in all, to eat under $10 for 2 is awesome!
author: Rachna P.

description: Halfway threw my meal I seen a mouse run across the floor!!! Didnt get a pic so I did not want to deal with asking for a refund. My mistake for not leaving after seeing a 88 health rating! Stay away!!!
author: Tafari G.

description:
I've only been here for lunch, and the food is A-OK.   Although the ingredients (hummus, falafel, tatzaki, toppings, etc.) are all out in salad-bar style-- you can't make custom wraps.  I wanted an eggplant/hummus/tatzaki schwarma.  All the ingredients were there.  But since it wasn't on the menu, they refused to make this very difficult custom order. I ended up with the veggie one, which was my original request plus falafel and onions.

The upside is that it's cheap.
author: Zuzzi E.

description: When I am wandering around Mission and realize that I am suddenly hunger, I am always glad to be near Ali Baba's. The food is cheap with large portions and they even have a cool low table in the back with draperies in case you really want to get in the Middle Eastern mood. I got a falafel wrap here and it was so big and warm and delicious that I could not have been happier. It was nice to have a break from the endless taquerias that all blend together. This offers the same quick service and food to satisfy your drunk hunger, but with a greater selection and a more interesting vibe.
author: Caitlin H.

description:
Bring your appetite, because you are gonna get SO MUCH FOOD. The cheap and tasty and filling falafel plate came with hummus, tabbouleh salad, yogurt/cucumber salad and  plenty of pocket pita bread. I'll be eating the other 2/3rds of the plate I got last night for lunch today...possibly dinner.

And this place is not a cave! It is roomy, well decorated for a place without waiter service and comfortable. There is even a little sitting room with cushions and tapestry and a very low-to-the-floor table.

In an area of town filled with cheap Mexican food, it's stellar to find Mediterranean food that won't break the bank.

Next time I'll get a sandwich, because they PUT FRENCH FRIES IN THEM. Holla!
author: Brittney G.

description: I like their falafel for lunch. Fast and cheap. Also, the staff is gentle. Even regular falafel is very long for Japanese, although they have "super falafel."
author: Kyoko T.

description:
I've been going to this place at least once a week for the last year or two, so I feel that's enough to justify the five-star rating. 
I'm the sort of person who only does things that I like to do. 
I've heard of some very strange people who do things over and over again even though they don't enjoy them, for instance:
"I fucking hate this damn coffee shop, but I go here everyday!" 
In addition to being rude, that's completely irrational and I would have to suggest to the person that they stop it immediately. It's masochistic. You always have choices, especially in a place like San Francisco. There are coffee shops and places to eat falafel everywhere! But I choose this place to go back to, over and over. That says a lot! It's not required for me to explain to you why I like this place. I've already demonstrated it. 

On one occasion I even came to this place twice in one day: 
I remember it well. I woke up and decided I wanted a falafel wrap, so I went and got it (again, because I'm the sort of person who always does exactly what I want to do when it is practically possible), later that day I ran into a friend who I was sleeping with at the time who wanted to eat Mediterranean food. I said, "Listen! I know just the place!" And can you guess where it was? If you can't you're not paying very close attention! It was this same place, Ali Baba's Cave!
So we went, and we had fabulous food. The man working that day gave me a slight smile acknowledging that it was my second visit. But I didn't mention it and neither did he. 
Well, I'm not sleeping with that person anymore. But I still often go to Ali Baba's Cave.

The moral of the story: this place is cool!
author: David V.

description: Wow! The only thing that Ali Baba and his shawarma thieves have stolen is my heart. This place delivers large portions of juicy lamb, beef, chicken, and falafel for a moderate price. Their sauces are flavorful and the service is fast. I've only been once, but was impressed by the portions, quality, price, and efficiency. Next time I'm in SF, I will definitely be coming back here.
author: Mike L.

description: Their falafel is definitely an amazing dish. Nice place for a meal. Sitting in their cave is fun too.
author: Joe Y.

description: I haven't had falafals like theirs before...crispy and moist....with combination of roasted eggplant.....interesting. I enjoyed it
author: S A.

description:
Wow, I've been going to Ali baba's for years going back to their original location on Haight and Fillmore but I haven't been for a while so I decided to pick up a shawerma and a side of babaganoosh last night. The price has gone up and that's expected but the Shawerma seemed small and the babaganoosh was way too lemony, lemon was the only discernible flavor. Also they didn't even toast the pita bread. The interior is dirty and falling apart, in desperate need of sprucing up. I wanted the turkey shawerma but could see the rotisserie was not working properly and I didn't want salmonella so I had the lamb instead

This was once a great place but seemingly no one cares about it any more.
author: Manny F.

description:
NOTE : I received a compliment on this review...If you want to read about it, go to my compliments. ;-)

This is for my 1 avid reader who never fails to make reading my YELP review a part of her everyday routine "GET A LIFE" (yes, he tells me you read it everyday, I guess since you cant see anything from my facebook account anymore)...thank you for taking time to read my reviews and he knows that im posting this too...i think he likes the drama, because he knows you will call him about this, but since i have already mentioned that im gonna put this one up at least the drama ends with you...according to him the difference between you and me, is that its okay with you to share him with everyone else, while i dont.

For all the official YELP readers, who uses this website for the purpose of it...i apologize for the inconvenience, after this I will not give this woman the satisfaction of  ruining  the good time I have going to the places I like with people that likes me and writing my reviews.

Oh and btw, I get private messages from people that are non-yelpers who doesnt have any reviews or friends on their profile, I have reported this to Yelp. They did the same thing on FB and I have reported that too.

Ring ring

Me : Hello (waking up voice)
Tb : Hello, what are you doing? Why arent you picking up my calls? I was calling you since Thursday. 
Me : You called???
Tb : I called you Friday, Saturday, Sunday
Me : I didnt see any calls
Tb : That's BS, I called your home and your cell.
        I want to see you last Sat so I can teach you to play golf, I was going to ask you to meet me at the driving range near my house. Where were you?
Me : Oh, so what did you do instead?
Tb : I just cleaned out my garage
Me : Can you clean my room?
Tb : If you want me to, where were you last Sat?
Me : I was at my cousins in Vallejo
Tb : What did you do Sun?
Me : I went to the driving range with my cousins
Tb : Where? Near my house?
Me : Yeah, we had hecka fun
Tb : So are you buying me lunch? (his indirect invitation for he knows he always pays for lunch ...lol)
Me : Nope, Im $1300 poorer now,
Tb : LOL oh because of your clubs huh, you should have taken me with you when you got them, who did you go with?
Me : Hmmm, my friend.
Tb : Okay, let me buy you lunch.
Me : I will only go to lunch with you when you swear on your mom's grave that you are not going to see your exes.
Tb : Ok, I swear.
Me : Promise?!
Tb : I dont do anything with them, with one, we only go out to dinner and a movie, the other one, I just play golf and bowling with and the other one, I just help her tune up her daughter's and her car and help her fix her house, that's it, but I dont have s*x with any of them. and besides, they are still okay with the fact that i see and hang out with them all.
Me: I dont want you sleeping around and catch STD
Tb: I AM NOT SLEEPING WITH ANYONE!!! Believe me, they are just my friends and no benefits.
Me : Promise??? I only ask that you dont lie and start telling the truth
Tb : I ONLY ASK THAT YOU TRUST ME AND STOP ACCUSING ME OF LYING

So he finally said, let me call you when Im done and we go to lunch okay?

Just like our other outings he would ask first if its okay to have miditerranean, he knows my answer already for he knows I can eat anything.

Here's my review:

I have had lots of Shawerma in my life, I was introduced to it during my College years since I have a couple of Middle eastern classmates. I love the tahini and yogurt sauce, it goes well with the meat.

This place is one of those hole in the walls, there's not much to it, but you know its good because people come here for the food. They serve two meats, I am thinking the other one was either chicken or turkey and the other one was lamb. We ordered the lamb, Tb had the hummus, a little bit of spice, onions and potatoes. I ordered mine without the potatoes but I asked for the tahini and he asked me, "what was that?"...i said "tahini" , so he asked the server to add to this to  his too.

We ordered our juice drinks, mango then we were served the food. Like always, we said grace, i love it when he leads the prayer. The shawerma was huge, like your super burrito, but it was good. All the flavors came together. The meat was good too. 

The service was pleasant, the place is okay so its all good.

We came, we ate and had fun with our afternoon delight. 

Will definitely come back and I recommend it if you need your quick shawerma fix. ;-)
author: Malou C.

description: Good food, good prices, and good people behind the corner. I've never had a neutral interaction during my visits.  Always very helpful and friendly. Dig this place when I'm in my Mediterranean phase.
author: stuart l.

description:
worstest  best place for good food and a memorable experience..
but I just wont get into the stuff I seen here cause I wouldn't  want those suckas at public health going nuts here
I'll just say I have driven up here from so cal plenty of times just on a craving for them wraps cause that dang hot sauce makes them happen oh so good
the  falafels are best
the shawarma I think is a bit gamy so I prefer the chicken kabob wrap although it does take like 20 minutes to grill and it tends to be easily overcooked. 
The lamb is strong on that lamb flavor but pretty good if you like lamb allot.
when in the bay I always eat here first and then pick up a couple of wraps for the drive home, dont care if it makes a big mess this place is clearly not for ocd neatos.
author: Xsurpt Z.

description:
Food is okay, but the portion is what makes coming here worth it. $7.50 (after tax) for a schwarma large enough to feed two - gotta love that! Plus, they close pretty late at 11pm.

JONASAPPROVED!
author: Jonas T.

description:
Ali Baba, Master of the Falafel.
Mari C., Easily Impressed by the Power of Garbanzo.

What the hell is in the Falafel Sandwich of Epic Proportions?  The eggplant has to be filled with crack, and the hummus tainted with pure delight.  Holy garbanzo it is frickin delicious!  AND HUGE.  AND CHEAP.

I bought the thing for a late lunch and ended up snacking the end at home before a night out with the roomies.  After a series of VERY GENEROUS "okay, sure you can have a bite"s to my roommates, they demanded that I lead them back to The Cave to replicate the experience.  

Since then (five days ago), my neighbor has been back four times and we have plans to return on Friday.  I'd say we've found a gem hiding in the depths of this Mediterranean hideout...
author: Mari C.

description:
Lamb schwarma is tasty. It's a bit pricey ($7+), but you get a freaking huge schwarma. I just wish they made something smaller for less.

The "cave" was disappointing. It's more of a "nook" or "cranny" or "alcove". But then no one would visit "Ali Baba's Nook" doesn't have the same ring to it.

The potato french-fry things in the schwarma remind me of Giordano Bros.' "all-in-one" sandwich: http://www.yelp.com/biz/giordano-bros-san-francisco
author: Rob T.

description: A helluva a lot of food for very little money. I'm talking Midwestern portions. It looks divey, but the food is really, really good. Only been there once, but I would go again and again for cheap Middle Eastern eats!
author: Jeff R.

description: This place is amazing and is the best place to go in the mission if you want your dollar to go far. The service was friendly, caring, and personable. The food was beyond what I was expecting. It was out of this world and Ali Baba's place is my go to lunch stop in the city. If you have not been yet...GO! You are missing out!
author: Molly A.

description:
best F-ing lamb sawarma's I've had in my life!  Under $8.  God dang they are soooo good.  If you're really hungry get a side of potatoes (they're home made french fries) and you can split them with some one else.  I like my sawarma a little more spicy, so I ask for a little extra hot sauce, but be careful, cause that hot sauce they have can creep up on your ass and ruin your damn sawarma!  "JUST A LITTLE".  

There's also a little table with pillows real low to the ground in the rear to the left where you and all your friends can sit on the carpet and act like your cultured.  
5 STARS
author: Joel J.

description:
The service is great, and the Falafel is huge.

I like all the things they put in it, but it was unfortunately dry for a number of reasons:

1) the bread. they don't use fresh pita, and they don't make their own lavash for the wrap, so the one they use is pretty dry and cracks as you eat it. fine, but then the inside needs to have something a little juicier

2) the veggies. i just got back from berlin, where they always give you a delicious garlic sauce, fresh tomatoes, and lettuce with your falafel. unfortunately, there were none of these fresh, tasty ingredients. no tzatziki, nothing creamy, not even enough hummus. instead, there were potatoes and eggplant, both of which are starchy, and so the falafel lacked some acidic/zesty tones.

3) after i got home, i was so thirsty. i realized that there might have been either msg in the falafel. either way, while i was eating, it was a little over-salted.
author: Bootylicious J.

description:
My favorite here is the falafel wrap.  I'm not a vegan or vegetarian or whatever, but I think the falafel wrap is way better than the shwarma wrap they have here.  I ask for extra hot sauce (really good) and request that eggplant be added in my wrap, and tell them not to give me any fries.

They're really generous with the fillings, but sometimes the fillings break the bread, making it kind of hard to eat.  Yeah it happens sometimes, but I don't mind cuz I'm smart enough to figure out how to get it all in my mouth.

The owner looks kinda pissed off all the time, but I think that's just his normal facial expression, because when you talk to him, he's really welcoming.  

As for their other stuff:

Round bun thing...I didn't really like it very much.  Tasted like they added a lot of herbs and spices.  It was sweet, savory and buttery.  I don't think i'm used to the flavors

Shwarma.. the meat is really tough, and lacks much flavor, especially the turkey. 

the hummus... very bland but the texture is nice

arabic coffee.. holy hell this stuff is strong.  i like it.  i like the fact that it has way less cardamom than old jerusalem's arabic coffee.  you can actually taste coffee here lol

Anyway, 5 stars for their falafel wrap...so crunchy, juicy and tasty. 
2.5 stars for their other offerings.
so 4 stars overall...
author: Jung L.

description:
I have a real tendency toward the overblown. I'm verbose, overly demonstrative, pushy, quixotic, and sappy. Especially about times past, cherished memories, the days of yore, yada yada. So I'm often surprised and disappointed when I revisit something from my past and it isn't bathed in golden sunlight and carried in on the wings of cherubim. I am certain this defect is a contributory factor to my dismal world view. It's hard to be perpetually let down, you know?

Anyway, I recently paired a shawarma from Ali Baba's and a chance encounter with a neglected part of my past; unexpectedly, of course. It was a strange juxtaposition: forced memories of childhood acquaintances wrapped in lavash and covered in an oppressive hot sauce. I had always held that part of my childhood so close to my heart; especially when I was living the dirty, broke ass green party mission rat life and eating Ali Baba's every day wishing I could be ten years old again and surrounded by precocious, privileged, self-confident private school girls. But now, forced to conjure up those memories into something real and tangible, they seemed to fall apart in front of me, like stale lavash too wet from the soggy-bottomed insides.  Were they ever even friends?
author: Megan W.

description: Haven't been to the restaurant yet but they catered an event for me tonight. Cannot complain about a single thing, food was well seasoned and simply amazing. Best mediterranean food I've had and trust me I've had plenty of it....Everything was wonderful. So glad I chose them
author: Bruna A.

description:
I'm a falafel purist.  

Call me hick, call me stubborn, but I like my falafel without the crazy bells and whistles that are slowly tainting the falafel sandwich population.

The following just do not belong:

Potatoes 
Roasted vegetables  
Cucumbers 

Don't get me wrong, I love all of the above, especially veggies.  Just not in my beloved falafel sandwich.  

What I do love is lots of hummus, tahini and chili, all of which Ali Baba's scrimps on.
author: Christine M.

description: Been here but it isn't remarkable...
author: Jeremy S.

description:
Shhhhhhh.  I'm going to tell you the secret of Ali Baba's.

Are you listening?

They close at 11pm.  Go in there at like 10:40, and order some tabouli and hummus.  It is so delicious, and they will give you like heaps and heaps of it because they're closing soon and they want to get rid of it.  And it'll still only be like $3.25 or some absurdly cheap price for the amount of side dish Mediterranean goodness you will get.

They'll already have the chairs up on the tables so you won't be able to eat it there, but you can go sit on the curb at that park across the street and stuff your face while the richies from Range walk by and look at you distainfully.  (Don't get me wrong, I'd totally allow myself to be taken on a date to Range.  But an Ali Baba's night is different from a Range night, and this review is about an Ali Baba's night.  So I'm ragging on the richies.)

Don't say I never told you any good secrets.  Go, eat.
author: Megan D.

description:
+HUGE wraps.

+Pretty decent tasting falafel.

+Takes cards.

+Great price for the amount of food you get.

-"Chef" NOT wearing gloves while preparing food.

-"CHEF" LICKING HER FINGERS WHILE PREPARING FOOD, PROCEEDING TO CONTINUE PREPARING FOOD WITHOUT WASHING HANDS. DURING A SWINE FLU "OUTBREAK," NO LESS.

-Weird small child, under the age of 5, wiping down tables and taking an unnatural interest in the only table occupied in the establishment (mine). Standing watching us, reaching her hands into the vicinity of our bags. Staring. Where are her parents?
author: Caitlin B.

description:
Two words: food poisoning. 

Granted it can happen anywhere, my boyfriend and I both got food poisoning after eating at Ali Baba's Cave on Sunday, October 28, 2007 at 9:30PM. I ordered the fallafel platter, and my boyfriend the lamb platter. It was tasty enough and was actually quite ffilling. 

About an twenty minutes after leaving the restaurant, we both felt bloated and heavy in our stomachs. Assuming we had just over-eaten, we both passed out and fell asleep. At about 3:30AM I woke up with a sudden urge to relieve myself on the toilet. Ten minutes of diarreah later, I began throwing up. I continued to throw up for the next twelve hours, every 1 1/2 hours or so, in between which time I had musle aches and spasms, and a fever of 100 degrees F. My boyfriend had diarreah as well for the entire next day.

The next day I suffered from more stomach cramps and diarreah. Today is the third day since eating at Ali Baba's Cave, and I am somewhat back to normal, though I could hardly sleep last night due to my stomach turning and aching.

I have never had such a violent reaction to food. I have called the CDC and the San Francisco Department of Public Health Food Poisioning Department to remedy the problem. I can only assume that others who ate there on Sunday night, had a similarly horrendous experience. I only wish restaurants would be more conscious of these types of issues. 

Do not eat here. I never will again.
author: Ryan R.

description:
Lamb is not cut thinly like I like it.  Falafel is often cold.  I love their spicy tabouli.  Great hummus.  Okay eggplant.  Small portions for what you pay.  Not too big on the customer service.  Hard to park, especially on weekends with all the Wuppies (White Urban Pros).  They accept credit cards.  I'm never sure of what the difference is between the chicken and the turkey, and I don't think the workers do either.

Update on 6.21.13

This place closed at 10:54pm, not 11:00pm, after I rushed from the Inner Richmond.  I called the guy from outside the restaurant, and he wouldn't let me in.  I've been going here since they opened, and this is how they treat me?  He had a friend in the store, so maybe they had hot dates or something ... Yeah right!!!  F 'em.
author: Dicky V.

description:
Ali Baba's Cave was a great first-time experience for Falafel in the Mission. Not knowing a lot about Greek food, I chose what seemed easiest--Falafel.

It was huge & quite yummy! My pal Scott and I realized that we should have split a Falafel instead of purchasing our own & leaving the leftovers on a trashcan outside for the Mission' homeless and/or hungry population.

The sandwich (or should I call it a burrito) itself was not too spicy, I actually would have liked it with a little more punch. Perhaps this is something you can ask for when ordering? I will try it next time.

Service was plain & simple--the counter person wasn't very friendly, but not much should be expected in this type eating environment.

This eatery has a great selection of soda pop--all from some obscure company and great tasting.

I'm giving it four stars because I assume there is a better Falafel (at least for me) out there, but the amount of food you get for the price is righteous.
author: matt m.

description:
i ordered the falafel sandwich and some dolma.
really cool decor and some interesting seating

for a small amount of money you get a large amount of good food
 order as you go kind of thing so there was no wait for the food. 
the lady that helped us was really friendly and nice
author: Adriana K.

description: I give it more 3.5, only because my husband said his beef shawerma was kinda bland. I had a falafel wrap and while it was good, I think the ones from Truly Mediterranean are better. But you get a huge amount of food for cheap, I would definitely come here again. Their falafels do have great texture and are tasty, but they're missing something. The falafel balls themselves aren't very flavorful I noticed when I ate a bit of one that fell out, so that could be it.
author: salini k.

description: Had the lamb shawarma in lavash bread.  FINALLY FOUND A PLACE THAT MAKES REALLY GOOD DELICIOUS SHAWARMA!  It wasn't served in a pita.  The lamb off of the spit had great bbq flavor.  All the right textures.  Great price.  Take that Sunrise Deli!  This was served right and about twice the value.  This meal took me to my happy place.  I think this the best value I've found on all of Valencia Street, and maybe in all of SF.  The last time I had something advertised as Shawarma that lived up to the title was about four years ago in Los Angeles.
author: Brian C.

description: I used to think this place made the best falafel shawarma.  But, now I've got a bunch of others to compare Ali Baba's against (Good Frikin' Chicken, Progressive Grounds) and here's the difference: the french fries.  Ali Baba's got 'em.  Others don't.  Now, depending on the day, that's either a good thing or a bad thing for me.  To grease or not to grease, that *is* the question.
author: Cassidy P.

description:
I had lunch at Ali Baba's Cave last week on the same day as the BIG storm. People were milling about more than usual, just like after the Loma Prieta earthquake. Natural weather events spark people's need to have comfort food and my desire that day was to have a lamb shawarma. The place was pretty crowded with other like-minded folks thinking - we need comfort from the storm (all the power outages and fallen tree branches!)

I usually go to Truly Mediterranean, but I think Friday is their chicken shawarma day and I wanted lamb so I came here. 

I ordered the said lamb shawarma and a side of humous. The shawarma was huge and very meaty. Very lamby tasting, more so than Truly Mediterranean. The humous was good but I like it more garlicy than they make it. They put more stuff in the shawarma than others I've had, but that doesn't really make it better, just bigger. 

I still think I like Truly Mediterranean better, but this place was good and satisfying, just different. from TM. I will come back and try other items, I had the falafel here awhile ago, but I don't remember anything about it.
author: Yvette K.

description:
For 5 bucks I can get a falafel sandwich the size of my head, which is ridiculously large--my head, I mean, not the sandwich. The sandwich is only ridiculous in terms of how delicious and cheap it is! The falafel, eggplant, tahini, hummus, hot sauce and vegetables are all wrapped in a slab of pita, rather than stuffed inside. According to my observations, this allows more space which allows more fabulous falafel to enter my greedy mouth. 

The restaurant itself is pretty gnarly and sometimes the kids working are, um, less than pleased to help you, but who cares! You can't go wrong with this place, especially if you take it to go for a picnic at Dolores Park or to accompany your beer at any neighboring bar.
author: Chloe S.

description:
When I was staying in New Zealand and on a very tight budget, I practically lived on kebabs which always came wrapped up like a burrito and slathered in tons of different sauces. Because they were such a dietary staple for me, I began to crave them all the time. And, when I got back to the states, I still wanted them, but had the hardest time finding kebabs that approximated the ones in New Zealand.

I am happy to say that the shawarma wraps at Ali Baba's are the closest that I have found in California. They are really delicious and you can easily get two meals out of them. If you like spicy food, be sure to ask for hot sauce -- it really makes the wrap delicious.  Service can be a little slow and the fries in the wrap take some getting used to. Ifyou are feeling bad about being unhealthy or don't like the fries substitute them for eggplant.  And since I can't just pop over the New Zealand every time I want a kebab, I will happily settle for the ones here.
author: Rebecca H.

description:
I always forget about this place when I'm in the neighborhood.  Then, after I've eaten my fourth burrito that week, I remember Ali Baba's Cave and regret my forgetfulness.

This isn't the best Middle Eastern food in the world, but it's really good, is cheap, and the people who work here are nice.
author: John S.

description:
All places that give you this much food for such a great price deserves 4 stars.  It's not the best, but it's tasty and CHEAP.  We sat in this nasty little room in the back.  Where you get to sit on cushions that look incredibly dirty and await your food.  One of our friends got a kabab here and it took FOREVER to arrive.  We were already done eatting by the time hers finally came.  But it was a lot of food and I don't think any of us finished our dishes. (Easily shareable in groups)

On a sidenote: We snuck in beers since it was very hidable while in that tiny room in the back.  (I doubt this place is BYOB, but it should be damnit.) ^_^;
author: Mary R.

description:
Meh. 

I mean sure its not bad, but its not great either.

I also hate them for making me think that dough poof thing would be more exciting than I thought. It was slightly uncooked & tasted like thawed out once frozen veggies. 

At least they got the Tabbouleh right.
author: Rebekah K.

description:
A very solid 4-stars from me.  The lamb shawerma is delicious and verrrry filling---an incredible amount of good food for around 6 dollars.  It's definitely a "damn, I'm hungry" kind of place.  The service is always friendly and accomodating, and when the owner's in, he greets the customers with a smile and gets busy behind the counter with the crew.

I usually go in the afternoons for lunch, which can tend to get busy---expect to wait around 5 minutes---once you see them create that delightful shawerma then grill it to crisp the wrap, you'll be glad you came!  Oh, and get extra hot sauce; it kicks ass.
author: Randy F.

description:
You can get a falafel wrap the size of my arm!
With the works eggplant, potatoes, hot sauce.

I don't care if people say this place is dirty. IT'S CHEAP. Just don't sit in that disgusting cloth-covered corner, unless you have huge dredlocks and are into that kind-of stuff.
author: Lauren W.

description: I had the falafel and it is fantastic. You get it for $6 and its enormous. Would be two meals for most folks. I'm not exactly a falafel connoisseur but I've had my share in the City and for me this is up there with the best of them, especially considering the price and the neighborhood.
author: Ben M.

description:
When I am in New York, I miss the Mexican food.  When I am in SF, I miss the Middle Eastern food.  The grass is always greener on the other side.

This is the neighborhood cheap Middle Eastern eats in the Mission.  But I used to live in Astoria in NY which is surrounded by an insane variety of Middle Eastern restaurants in the same way that one is surrounded by an insane variety of Mexican restaurants in the Mission.  

It's a letdown...Middle Eastern cusine-wise.  They heated my food for me in a microwave oven and it wasn't warm all the way through.  And it seemed to have dried out from sitting around all day long.

However, I give it 3 stars because I've seen the restaurant owner be plenty nice to the vagrants who walk on the block.
author: Sooj O.

description:
And today I learned - get it 'for here'.  The wraps do not work for 'to go' street walking eats.   The wrap was leaking like crazy.  I made a mess of myself but it was my fault.

So so wrap.  Not bad if you are in the mood and in the neighborhood.  I have been eating so much Mediterranean food lately that the REALLY good places have made places like this seem less than awesome.  With that in mind 2.5 stars.
author: Jason H.

description:
Friendly people. Large portions for the price. Great if you want to try something different while traveling.. Cool vibe.

Get the shawerma.
author: Kimiko S.

description: The deluxe falafel is made with delicious eggplant and homemade french fries.  One is enough to feed a couple and at this price it is the best meal deal in SF!
author: Melanie R.

description:
I've been disappointed with my last few visits to Ali Baba.  The falafels are dry and  the hummus bitter.

The portions are large, and some of the dishes I haven't tried look good, but you'll have to try for yourself - I've headed on up to Truly Mediterranean on 16th.
author: Bill V.

description:
Oh boy, this place is pretty bad.
I ordered falafel, and what I got was burned, cold, and very bland. Worse even, the ingredients tasted [and looked] like they'd been sitting out for several hours! Why would you feed that to people?
The place was dirty, too. I actually felt like I needed to wash my hands for touching the table I was sitting at, and it looked like the staff wasn't even bothering with cleaning the dining area at all.
Gross, gross, gross.
Next time, I'll walk the extra coupla blocks to Truly Mediterranean.
author: Erin P.

description:
yum, yum and yum!
Nothing like Mediterranean burritos.  This puts me back in Holland where you can get Shwarma and falafel in a vending machine.  These are even better.    
If I could have sat in the cave you would have gotten 5 stars.  The atmosphere is so so.  I will be back in hopes of sitting in the cave.
author: Maggie K.

description:
The folks at Ali Baba apparently speak in a foreign tongue.  As a public service advisory, I will do all of my Yelper buddies the service of translation:

What I said to the dude behind the counter:  "Hi, I'd like a chicken kebab plate with hummus and salad, please."

What the dude behind the counter heard:  "You will wait forever for your food at a dirty table no one has bothered to wipe down.  Then when I do finally give you a plate of food, it will be missing one kebab, 'cause I mistakenly sold it to someone else while you were waiting half of your adult life for your lunch.  So you will take one kebab now, and you can wait for the other some more.  Go ahead and eat (good luck finding a clean fork! Bwahahahahaha! /points and laughs/), even though all your friends already finished eating their wraps and are just looking at you bored and wishing you'd just take your late, incomplete order to go." 

Hatechoosomuch!

Minus one star for being so dirty.
Minus another star for making me wait 25 minutes for a stupid kebab.  Plus 10 more for the other one. 
Minus another star for selling one of my kebabs to some other dude while I waited for my order.  
Minus a fourth star for *all* of your wall hangings being crooked.  This bugged me.  So did my afternoon stomach ache.
Minus a fifth star for... oh, wait.

If you speak "Ali Baba", you obviously have more patience, higher tolerance, a stronger digestive constitution, and greater forgiveness than I do.  Godspeed.
author: Caroline E.

description:
Just as a note: I always get the same thing here: falafel wrap with the works.  That doesn't really change, so I can't speak to the rest of the menu, though everyone I've ever taken here has been pleased with the meal, regardless.

I like this place.  The portions are huge and the prices are low.  And it isn't a burrito.  I've always had good service here- prompt and really friendly. My wrap is always delicious, if way too much food for me to finish in one sitting.  I wouldn't call it "amazing" cuisine, but for the price, it's quite good.  Some of it is a bit under-seasoned, maybe, but when I go here I'm not looking for a fancy meal, so I enjoy it all the same.
There's never a long ling (also a plus), but they do seem to have a strong following.  And since I've been coming here for a few years, it's nice to have someplace on which I can rely.  It's definitely a go-to place when I'm sick of burritos, don't want to cook and have no time.  

Plus their eggplant is amazing.  No matter how hard I try, my grilled eggplant is just never as good.
author: Christy T.

description:
The lamb shawarma sounded like a good idea, but it was a complete mess that fell apart after a few bites...

There was gristle in the meat as well...

The place needs a thorough scrubbing to boot...
author: Nathan W.

description: Oh My God . . . I was ordering a Falafel on Monday January 7th, 2013 at 12:30 PM, the "Chef" was talking on his cell phone while making my Falafel. He did not wash his hands before touching the bread. While I was eating, he sat at a table near the front door, and chewed his fingernails while talking on the phone. He had his fingers in his mouth! Another customer came in and ordered a Falafel. I watched hoping he would wash his hands. He did not. He touched the food with the same fingers he had in his mouth moments before. GROSS! I really like the Falafels there, but not the grungy atmosphere, disgusting bathroom, and the chef not washing his hands or using gloves. To the owner of this restaurant: Please have your employees wash their hands, keep their fingers out of there mouths, and remodel your bathroom and keep it CLEAN. THE RESTAURANT NEEDS A GOOD CLEANING TOO!
author: Albert H.

description: amazing fresh wraps (huge), fast service. cool seating area.
author: Robyn H.

description:
I kind of agree with the other reviewers.  This place is alright but there are definately plenty of other more tastebud friendly greek/mediterranean restaurants around.  We went to Ali Baba's b/c it was close to my office, it wasn't terrible, I've just had better food elsewhere.

We ordered two veggie combo plates, 1 side of dolmas, and 1 iced tea, the total came out to $17.45, plus with tip, I shelled out $20.  The portion size was decent on the combo plates but I was a bit disappointed with the meagre 4 dolmas they gave for the side order, I think 6 would have been more fair.  As for taste, food was good, for great I'd recommend Truly Mediterranean or Myconos.  The service was also mediocre, "curt" would be the best adjective, but not "mean" or "friendly."  

As for the venue, there is a red theme going on and it does feel like you're in a Greek restaurant, which is nice.  Also it's not noisy so you don't have to shout (a bonus for lunch meals!).
author: Swetha G.

description:
The bomb shwarma.  Eating area is kinda messy.  Watch out for the druggies hanging around the corner.

Their deluxe falafel shwarma is ginormous.  even the regular sized one I don't finish.  

Love the fries they put inside lol.
author: Dong T.

description:
When I crave dolmas and a chicken schwarma wrap, this is where I inevitably go.  I've strayed to other places in the Mission, and when I do, I've always been disappointed.  

With the chicken schwarma, they start with a little hot sauce (since their sauce has some kick, I opt for a sparing amount), nice roasted eggplant (in the shape of french fries), and a generous amount of yummy chicken.  I love the fact that they toast the sandwiches for you.  With the dolmas, I always ask for a little yogurt sauce accompaniment, which they happily oblige.

Pluses: Chicken Schwarma wrap, Falafel, and the Dolmas are my faves.

Minus: For those with cars, the 19th/Valencia corridor can be tough parking, so prepare to turn on your hazards and illegally park as you run into the restaurant to grab your food.
author: Jane A.

description:
Ok check it out.

You have 9 dollars. You are hungry but you want to have some money left for beer. What do you do? Go to Ali Baba's cave of course!!!
Get an enormous falafel for i think its 5.79 or something, i forget but it's so filling and tasty!

Eat in the cave and lye there for a second while you try to go figure out what beer you can get with your remaining dollars! 

Or come climb with me!
author: Dave M.

description:
The best falafel sandwich I have ever had, or that I've had since high school when my friend's dad served us homemade falafel in a pita with homemade potato chips tucked in side.

Since then, I've been limited to Daphnes and sometimes that Falafel Drive In down in San Jose, until now.

I admit that my first experience with Ali Baba's was while I was still reeling from drinking too much on an empty stomach but even then, as I was teetering and swaying slightly about, I could tell my tastebuds had stumbled onto something good.

That falafel sandwich is something I would stake my reputation on. Spicy hummus, fried eggplant, french fries, tahini sauce, tabouleh, cruchy-shelled falafels rolled in lavash. They call come together like a great rock band and it tastes just as good when I'm sober.
author: Y C.

description: Sadly I have to say this place has gone way down hill. That being said I haven't eaten here in over 6 months. The take away lamb kebab wrap was super dry, gristly and not appetizing to say the least. I would of thrown it away but after washing off the lamb chunks my dog happily ate the meat. Let's see how it turns out for him tomorrow. The portion was huge but I would have gladly eaten a much smaller portion of better quality. So my food after two bites is going uneaten...I guess that means looking in the fridge for something else for dinner tonight.  Also what happened to the super friendly staff that used to be here?
author: she o.

description: Great falafel! It was huge (2 meals for me), cheap (under $7 even with the 'deluxe' eggplant), just spicy enough, and delicious. Nothing better after hanging out in Dolores Park.
author: Lisa W.

description:
Fortunately for us, there are very good Arabic/Mediterranean places in the Mission so we don't have to step into this lame (at best) and stomach ache factory (usually).

The food is just not good, not by Middle East standards, and not by Mission Mediterranean food standards. Lattice in a falafel wrap? BIG no no. Might as well as well add some paper strips to make the pita look big.

And I wonder what the health inspectors in this city are doing. I can't see "your tax money at work" signs in their office when I got stomach aches two out of three times (bad ones!).

For falafel and wraps, Truly Mediterranean is still the king, Old Jerusalem for authentic, more upscale Fattoush, Medjool (well not strictly Mediterranean, but close enough) and a bunch of others. And then there is the rest of the city out of the Mission.

There is nothing more I can say about this place without using bad language, so lets stop here before this gets uncivilized.
author: Elija A.

description:
Food is cheap and in big portion, but personally not a big fan when it comes in taste.
My friend ordered a falafel dish and I think it's a bit on the hard side.. I have had better. My chicken shawarma was ok.. it's HUGE, but I suppose it would taste better if there's more eggplant and the fries weren't soggy. The sauce/hummus made it flavorful. And the hot source... is very spicy.
Staff was pretty friendly.
author: Doris H.

description: Everything had a slightly burnt taste to it which I did not appreciate at all. I had a chicken shawarma and it was ok. The baba ghanouj was disappointing as well. My friend had a shawarma plate and it too had the similar burnt taste. That completely ruined it for us
author: Srikanth R.

description: Long, hot, and inexpensive chicken shawarmaaa! I was very excited to eat you up, but you were no good after a few bites. You had plenty of chicken but you were quite dry. I only like you dripping with tahini sauce. At least your veggies were fresh and I had the pleasant experience of sitting on pillows in the corner with my friends under what felt like a colorful fort! I like forts!
author: Bets Y.

description:
Ok So I am little biased ( I live right across the street) but if you ever are craving something to blast your taste buds into overdrive, I dare you to order the lamb shawerma with extra hot sauce. It makes me cry! The falafel is crisp, just the right amount of chutzpah to fool your carnivorous teeth. The best part it's big enough for two and cheap to boot, a whole meal and drinks for under ten bucks!

The tabbouleh is perfect, a lively balance of parsley and lemon to cure that not so fresh feeling after a night of partying in the mission bars.

And if you ever find yourself having to host a dinner party and are running out time, the lamb and chicken kebabs are great for sharing and look totally home made ( who me? I'll never tell)
author: Ketan A.

description:
You don't go to Ali Baba's for a nice sit-down meal.  You don't come for decor, or sanitation, or pampering.  You come when you need absolutely the best falafel sandwich in San Francisco.

The wrap is crispy, the balls, flavorful.  The sauce, refreshing, the hummus, fresh and tart.  The available sides are quite good also- good for a tabouli freak like me.

Ask for extra hot sauce on the falafel if you need a good soul-cleansing..  So good!  In LH there are so many great cheap food choices, but ABC beckons at least bimonthly.  

As some have mentioned, you can stretch a quite servicable lunch and dinner out of one sandwich, for $5!  More money for beer is never a bad thing.  I generally end up stir-frying the contents of the 2nd half with some goodies and turn it into something else entirely.
author: George C.

description:
What happened?  

I use to love this place.  Well seasoned food and lots of it for a great price.  Shawermas WERE delicious.

Last night, the shawerma was full of cold potatoes, very little tzaziki or yogurt sauce.  I would have just notched this up an off night however, I think they must have changed ownership.  They no longer serve lamb shawermas because "lamb is too expensive" so I had to order the beef shawerma.

Definitely not the middle eastern food I was craving.  I'll give it one more shot in a few and see if this disappointment is permanent.
author: Johnny W.

description:
********THIS IS A GOOD PLACE - GO HERE.***********

FOOD 

who can complain about some really good FALAFEL???? the shawerma was delicious, a must have for the carnivores.

ATMOSPHERE

fast-food style, with plenty of tables and a really cool "cave" area in a corner, where you and your friends can sit on pillows and eat like SHIEKS!!! just kidding, but really, it is a lot of fun. they should really improve their dining room and bathroom, but i'm not a snob so i let it slide. the food is alright, i have had much better, but alas, that was in CHICAGO. go here if you are in the neighborhood, it is definitely worth it.
author: oskar p.

description:
Ali Baba's was the worst sit-down dining experience I've had in years.  My friend and I were hoping to have a quick dinner in the neighborhood and Ali Baba's seemed like a perfectly good, fast alternative to Mexican food.  We ordered, waited 45 minutes for our food in vain, asked where our food was twice, and finally ended up walking out an hour later with our food in plastic bags.  The staff there was unapologetic and unresponsive.  I wish I could say it was just a mistake and lack of customer service, but the staff there just didn't seem to put effort into anything.  

The inside of Ali Baba's is *disgustingly* dirty.  All available seating is filthy and shabby in that about-to-breakdown sort of way.  During my wait, I looked over at the wall next to me and realized the walls were not only dirt/smoke covered but also STAINED with caked on sauces that customers had spilled.  There were literally globs of crusted sauce on the walls.  It was just downright foul.  I spent the rest of my frustrating wait trying to avoid looking at the inside of the restaurant.  Note to self: never go to a "cave" to eat -- they have caveman standards for cleanliness.

When I finally bit into my lamb shish kebab sandwich at home an hour later, I couldn't help but notice that the chunks of lamb, onion and vegetables were way too big.  The sandwich itself was a good generous size but seriously, how much extra time does it take to cut ingredients into decent size cubes?
author: Fanzi P.

description:
Want to like it...I really do.  But it always is "a tad off".  
Flavors are never "in harmony".  
When it comes down to it, I just don't "like it".
author: Robby T.

description:
Best Falafel Sandwich EVER. 

And they have this cool little nook for your group to sit in with curtains and pillows on the floor. Even better! And I am convinced that anyone who complained about the service is working for a competing falafel joint.
author: Jessica W.

description:
Fun lunch.

Portions are epic. Shawerma is the size of a small child. 

Man working there was able to make recommendations and didn't slather too much hot sauce since I told him that I have a sensitive mouth.
author: Alli J.

description:
So, I ate here a few weeks back and the food was good but, I couldn't stop staring at the dirt all over the place.
I went again tonight, expecting it to be better in dim light.

And theeeeeennnn, a RAT came crawling out from behind the sheet they have in the corner booth thing.  It was terrible.
I will never go again.
Gross, gross, gross.  
I am having visions of the massive rat now.

Thanks, Ali Baba.
author: Meghan B.

description:
This place is YUMMY! And I don't think it looks dirty in there at all. In fact it looks like a kick back place to sit with a hookah, in the corner of the restaurant area. 

I got a felafel sandwich and it is THE best place to get falafel in the Mission. They put everything but the kitchen sink in it. French fries, eggplant, and generous portions of all else.
author: Jocie M.

description:
There's nothing like a shawarma the size of a grown man's forearm to pick you up again, and boy did I need a pick-me-up. After the most depressing job fair ever, this shawarma and this shawarma alone made the day all worth it.  (Will work for food. If you have a job, let me know, college grad with a BA)

I normally don't like making small talk with restaurant owners because I'm kinda introverted like that, but the dude behind the counter was just so bubbly that I had to ask his recommendation. It was a plus that there was a Yelp sticker on the door. He asked "vegetarian or meat." Meat all the way, baby. "Garlic or spicy?' Give me enough garlic to ward off the population of Transylvania. Hence me ending up with a chicken shawarma sandwich wrapped in lavosh (vs pita, how i have it everywhere else) 

The french fries in the shawarma was inspiring, and the chicken surprisingly juicy, though I think it may have been from the sauce more so than the how the chicken was cooked. 

My friend M had the falafel sandwich, which was pretty damn tasty too, but nothing beats piles and piles of MEAT. We both dominated our sandwiches within minutes and still had room for ice cream later (we puposedly walked really slow for 4 blocks and stopped a few times to make room though..)

The owner was a sweetie who brought out water for us, even though I went up to the counter to get it. The girl behind the register however totally ignored my request for water. Oh well, the food in my belly is still making me smile, so all good.
author: Kathy P.

description: biggest shwarma i've ever had! i went on a tuesday night and was lucky to get in before it closed but was unlucky in that they ran out of chicken but i guess that's what i get for going so late. my choices were falafel or lamb, i like falafel but i'm a carnivore so i went with the lamb. the potion of lamb was generous and was complimented well with the fries, eggplant and cucumber sauce. what i found interesting was their choice of using the lavash bread instead of the traditional pita-like bread, it was actually a nice change to the classic. the place was decorated nicely inside, if i ever make it back i was to sit and eat in the section that kind of resembles jeannie's bottle in "i dream of jeannie." and unlike a previous reviewer when i went the place was roach-free!
author: Michael G.

description:
No bullshit. Order your food, enjoy it, get the fuck out. 

Falafel is cheap, huge, filling, and delicious.

Eat there if you're in the area, not worth walking more than 5 blocks for.
author: Matthew F.

description: Sometimes I forget the name of certain Middle Eastern dishes and just ask for "Everything in a wrap, with hot sauce, please."  When I pulled this move at Ali Baba's Cave, they were determined to test my resolve.  They took out an enormous piece of flatbread and piled it high with eggplant, roasted potatoes, falafel the size the baseballs, hummus, and various other things, then wrapped it up and threw it on the grill.  The size of it was ridiculous--literally over a foot long and super-dense--but it was so delicious that I tried, and failed, to eat all of it.  For $7!
author: Christopher R.

description:
Pretty good food, decent prices, and good sized portions.  This is how Middle Eastern food is supposed to be, hearty, cheap, and yummy.  Al Baba's Cave does a good job of serving all of this up in a rather minimally decorated place a few blocks from the Valencia bar scene and Dolores Park.

I had the falafel plate, which was very good and piled high with hummus, tahini and the like.  The falafel was good, nicely fried on to outside,  delicious on the inside.

My only real complaint is that the pita bread was rather thin, and there wasn't much provided with my meal; I ended up eating a lot of my falafel balls without pita as I had run out already.

Overall though, I'd definitely recommend it, one of the better Middle-Eastern joints in the city.
author: Eric M.

description: Came here just two days after going to the Haight location and ordered the exact same thing- Lamb Schwerma.  It wasn't the same, and wasn't as good.  I'm not sure if it was because I was starving before the Haight location that made it so good... Anyway the prices were the same but the schwerma in the Mission was smaller and had a little less of everything in it.  Still giving it 3 stars, in case you get sick of cheap awesome mexican food, there is always some cheap middle eastern at ali baba's.
author: Skye W.

description:
The best falafel Shatangi has had in the city (Yet). I like the spicy sauce and the price.

Shatangi told you
author: Njon W.

description:
