Okay having lived in Dubai until 18 I think I know a good shwarma - unfortunately this one is not good...

greasy...check
dingy place....check
average service....check
food sitting around....check

Much better places for you to get your fix...myself I think I could eat Shwarma every day...Yumma's here I come...
author: Omer K.

description: Not fine dining. More a hole in the wall. Reasonably priced for a quick bite. Thought the stuffed pastry w/ rice was interesting though the flavors werent particularly refined.
author: Lisa C.

description: Shawarma is delicious and well prepared.  Real easy to eat on the go.  The service is fast and tacit, just what one expects from fast food Mediterranean.  My only criticism is that the beef was a little too charred but certainly not so bad.
author: Charlie H.

description: What other place puts french fries and potato salad in your falafel.  This is a great hole in the wall type of place with excellent food.  It's hard to read the menu, but just order the falafel with everything and you will be set.
author: Jonathan U.

description:
Not the best bargain in falafel/shwarma, but the food is definitely pretty good. You get a lot for your money (about 9 bucks for a lamb shwarma plate). I didn't love the falafel as much as Truly Mediterranean, but it was pretty tasty.

I did find some of the food to be very salty.
author: Dana L.

description:
Dinner.
The lamb plate was delicious and enormous.
Plate, tabouleh, babaganoush/hummus and rice.
The bread, is so thin that it gets crumbly pretty fast.
Eat quickly.
Don't forget the hot sauce... it is VERY spicy so get it on the side.
It was the first and hottest day of summer 2008!
They don't have ice.... just cold drinks....
author: Geordie E.

description: I usually pass on Mediterranean joints in America because the food tends to be greasy and generally unappealing. But this place is incredible! I had the falafel sandwich which was not only the best most delicious falafel sandwich that I have ever had, but plentiful enough for two and only $4.25!!! Another delightfully added surprise is that they have the Absolute best chai tea in the town - hands down! To boot - the staff are very freindly and they have an awesome cave like dining area in the back corner with a low table and pillows - quite the ambiance.
author: Jo A.

description:
Damn good baba ganoush (or however you spell that)!
Agree that the atmosphere leaves something to be desired, but more than enough for lunch.
author: Peter O.

description:
The lamb shawerma is only for those that really like lamb.  Nice and medium, fresh lamb flavor.  The only downside is that the fries they put in are not always hot, so you get the granularity of cold fries.  hence, the 4/5 stars.  This is what I pack for domestic flights where cheap ass airlines dont provide free meals.

If you only eat lamb because you are scared of BSE and e-Coli, then go to truly mediteranian on 16th, they are good also and great staff.  No essence of lamb there its more about spices.
author: H C.

description:
Just when I thought that I could not like this place more than I already did... 
after having had their falafel sandwich - which just might exceed a foot in length - on several, never-disappointing occasions... 
after having relished the fact that "with everything" means you get fried potato and eggplant in your sandwich... 
after having been startled by the rich flavor of staples like the hummous and baba ghanouj...
having more than once commented on the great value of everything on their menu, and how Ali Baba's makes a better quick meal than 90% of the burrito places in the supposed heart of SF Mexican food eating...

Just then, in late January (just before "Super Tuesday") I learned that I could love Ali Baba's even more when I noticed on my morning walk to BART that they had put an Obama 08 sign in their window.  

This place is great.
author: Josh C.

description:
I love Ali Baba's! Falafel wraps that last for two meals, friendly staff, and the food is just delicious. It's not the best, but it's definitely one of the better places to go when you want a quick bite to eat on a tight budget.

Eating there is not the best because it's so small and dank (hmmm... kinda like a cave??), so I'd suggest just taking your food to go as a picnic while on your way to Dolores Park. :)
author: Judy C.

description:
I've gone several times as I live pretty close, and the food is nearly always amazing. Other reviews note that it can be not as tidy of a place as you might hope--my sleeve stuck to the table! 

But I give it five stars, because the shawarma is absolutely amazing, and nearly a foot long! You can eat half right away and the other half reheats really well. The hummus is really good too. 

My advice, grab shawarma to go, and save your sleeves, but don't skip it just because it's not cozy and cute!
author: Angela G.

description: I'm pretty fussy when it comes to mediterranean food, and Ali Baba's just didn't deliver.  I got the falafel which didn't have much flavor and really wasn't fresh, and that describes the rest of my meal as well.  I know people who love the place but I really don't get the appeal....
author: Suzanne K.

description:
I always order the chicken schwarma, not sure how to spell it.  It is very flavorful, one of the best I have had.  I think what makes it flavorful is the sauce they use and the fries.  I would give it a higher rating but it almost always falls apart when I eat it, and that really bothers me.  

I am not fancy by any means, but truth be told, the place could use a scrubbing.
author: Jaime T.

description:
Fast, cheap, tasty. One of my weekly staples. I usually stick with the standard falafel deluxe, but if you can wait 5-10 minutes, go for the vegetarian shish kebab. It's truly superb.

That little cave in the back creeps me out. It smells intensely musty. I can't even believe people sit there. The rest of the place is, as others have said, not exactly spic-n-span either.

I also miss Ziandh (sp?), the guy who used to work there. The staff now are nice in general, but when you arrive at 10:30pm, they put on a faux-friendly voice and kindly inform you, "just wanted to let you know we're about to close." Yeah, in half an hour.
author: Blake E.

description:
Falafel with eggplant and french fries? YES!

Great cheap eat in the Mission. Large portions.
author: vicki c.

description:
First time here - loved the smoky baba ghanoush; excellent parsley-ey tabouleh; yogurt cucumber salad was good but a tad bland; the hummos nice and lemony, heavy on the tahini. I'd never had that thingy with the fried bulghur wheat with lentils - YUM.

Overall "tastes like homemade." Can't wait to go back and try more. Nice heaping servings. Great value.

There's a funny alcove with a big cloth where you could simulate (somehow) that you're in an exotic restaurant. Maybe if you BYO candle and finger cymbals.
author: Susie W.

description:
OK, so I've been to several other Middle Eastern restaurants in town (and in the Middle East) since coming here and it turns out that everyone and their mother puts fries in shawarma, except for every shawarma place in Davis. It's still really, really good.

Though I hear the health department gave these guys a very, very low score.

Still my favorite place to eat shawarma. Well, this place and Herbivore.
author: Amy Z.

description:
Great falafel wrap! Be careful when you ask for extra spicy sauce, it's killer! The hot plates heating the food? Whatever dude, as long as they stay deep fryin' and roastin' that meat I'm happy! And to all you people complaining about cleanliness or having to "scrub the walls down," chill out and bring some damn hand sanitizer with you, clean freaks. The food is meant to be eaten with your hands. 

Great food, and cheap. Another plus is the creepy old guy in the business suit that yaks at the owner guy and hits on the female cook. Adds a delightful atmosphere to this establihment, 4 1/2 outta 5 baby!
author: Mike H.

description: This cave of sorts had an amazing spread of options and the tabouleh was to die for along with the mouth watering grape leaf dolmas.  This is one of those true San Francisco hole in the wall places that has much more than meets the eye.  The staff is incredibly friendly, very fast and can deal with the rush really well.  I was also a huge fan of the falafel wrap. I love that the wrap had the friend eggplant and fries in there! Great place for vegetarians!
author: Ankit J.

description: I dream about their shawerma's!  So...I absolutely love their huge drippy juicy shawerma's, juice splashing on my shirt does in no way deter me from their delicious cave.  The price is soooo right for someone who barely has any $ to spare!  I think they are $7 and will fill you will meaty goodness until breakfast!  The people are always nice and quick.  The only reasons I would not give a higher rating for this yummy tiny hole in the cave is because I have nightmares about their bathroom (one of the top two scariest I have seen in the city) and the fact that they broke my shawerma heart when they said the last time that lamb is now too expensive to offer!!! Whaaaaaaaaaat?! That is one of the main reasons I go there...for the succulent lamb.  Waaaaaah.  Well, I do admit...the chicken shawerma was delicious too, as well as the stuff my friend ordered.  Please have lamb the next time I visit!   Baaaaaaaaaaaaaaah.
author: Delicious B.

description: Consider "A.B.C." purely a take-out joint.  Why?  Because once you pass the cash register the balance of the restaurant is dirty, dirty, dirty.  And, I don't even want to think about what lives under the tent in the cave room.  All of the food is good and the portions are generous so bring along your re-usable bag and take your food away.
author: P. G.

description:
Had lunch, very good serving size more then plenty for the price, lamb was good...service could of been a tad better, pretty no-frills place.

I was well sated after my meal, though.
author: Tiberius A.

description:
Big disappointment.  I ordered a regular falafel sandwich and the woman behind the counter asked if I wanted it "with everything".  I said yes, assuming she meant everything that comes with the regular sandwich, but apparently saying yes meant she automatically upgraded my order to the pricier super sandwich.  This is bullshit.  I didn't say anything; I was hungry and tired and I don't want to have to be a bitch when I go out for a quick bite to eat, but I didn't appreciate it.  

As for the food, the sandwich was gigantic, but it was mostly glop.  I love hummus, baba ghanouj and tahini sauce, but whatever the glop was, it wasn't very flavorful and it made up most of the volume of the wrap.  Suspended in the goop were some chunks of cucumber, parsley branches, greasy potatoes and eggplant, and a few soggy, stale falafel balls. I can only assume the folks who rated this place highly have never had really good falafel. ..I guess when there isn't a ton of competition, you can get away with being mediocre.  I definitely won't be back.

On the positive side, at least the toilet was flushed....
author: Susan B.

description:
I want to like this place.  It's right around the corner, has huge servings for cheap, and has nice atmosphere.  But in my only visit, I had greasy eggplant and my friend was knocked out for the rest of the day by whatever she had.  

That said, I'm still going back  - it was hopefully an off day!
author: Elliott W.

description:
I'm getting hungry just THINKING about my review.

This place has got the best vegetarian falafel I have EVER had.  Not only is it stuffed generously with yummy potatoes/fries, eggplant, and the perfect amount of spice in addition to all the other good stuff, but it is the length of my size ten foot AND it's really cheap (something like 5 bucks).  Not to mention the people behind the counter are always friendly and sweet.

Totally Lebanese/Israeli foodish and I love it!
author: avisha c.

description:
My favorite falafel in the city so far. The sandwich is gigantic and they include all sorts of stuff if you want it. Such items include roasted potatoes, grilled eggplant, cucumber/diced tomato mix, tahini and hot sauce.

If you're a "purist" you could always just ask nicely to leave off any of the above. I prefer it to be on there, as it adds a bit of variety to an old standard. 

Also, they sell Nantucket Nectars "Half & Half". It's the perfect accompaniment for this sandwich on a warm day.
author: aaron f.

description:
My fat ass couldn't finish off the falafel wrap. It was huge. So I had to take it home to finish. Where was Kirstie Alley when you need her lard ass?

Not the best but hits the spot (without denting your wallet).
author: Rocky K.

description:
This place is a regular lunch visit for me. Solid, dependable, affordable. Try the lamb shawarma, but get it to go -- the interior is musty and dark.

Location: right next to my house! 1 star.
Service: efficient counter service. 1 star.
Atmosphere: none to speak of. 0 stars.
Decor: faded, tacky. -1 star.
Food: plentiful and extremely tasty. 1 star.
Prices: value-packed. 1 star.

This is good food let down by grimy walls and dusty plastic plants. Buy food here and take it to Dolores Park.
author: Laurie V.

description:
Falafel sandwich, with everything on it. Spicy. 

"Everything" means onions, potato wedges, eggplant, hummus, parsley, and jerusalem salad. All wrapped up in a big piece of lavash bread with 4 falafel balls and grilled to perfection. This thing is like 12" long; it's a big meal. I split mine with a friend. 

My one complaint is that it took longer than I expected it to, but the quality is definitely there. Recommended.
author: Marc K.

description:
on my last trip, i saw the falafel sandwich and so badly wanted to try it but alas, there aren't enough meals in a day!

though still full from lunch at burma superstar just hours ago, marc k. suggested we split a falafel sandwich.  remembering my regret from a year ago, i was not going to let a full stomach stop me so i gladly complied.  it's the same size as, but 50 cents more than, a 5-dollar-footlong subway (and now that they've caught on, 5-dollar-footlong quizno's); fifty cents more for eggplant (which we got).  

one thing this sandwich sports that no other falafel sandwich i've had has: potato wedges, aka "french fries".  good idea.  i love this vegan sandwich.
author: Gail T.

description:
Went here for a late lunch today . . . what turned out to be a very dry, unsatisfying late lunch.  I had a falafel sandwich; my dining companion had a turkey schwarma.  Both were very dry and not terribly enjoyable to eat.

Perhaps the gentleman behind the counter was having a bad day.  He seemed less than pleased about our request for water, and after asking us to please sit down, made a point of basically throwing our two wraps on top of two plates on our table.  Very strange experience overall, and I wasn't convinced about the cleanliness of the place.

I won't be returning.
author: Pam M.

description:
I don't have any other reviews on here, but I HATE this place (both locations) so much that I have to tell the city about it.

These people are absolutely retarded.  I brought a party of four in to the Haight location for lunch and every body wanted a schwarma plate.  We all tried to order per the menu, specifying our meat and salads and the counter person looked at us like we were from outer space.

This has happened to me at both locations.  For some reason there is a SERIOUS language barrier and their staff is under trained.

The food is decent but not worth putting up with the aggravation.
author: Steve P.

description: It hurts me to give Ali Baba's Cave three stars. A couple of years, i would have given it a 5er. I remember driving all the way from the peninsula to SF just to have one of their Shwarma sandwiches (they put fries and eggplant in it which is just fantastic). But my experience this past weekend at Ali Baba's cave was really disappointing: I got the chicken shwarma platter (I know you should get lamb and for the platter get the shish kababs) and the chicken seemed undercooked. It had no flavor and was a very far cry from Ali Baba's hey day. The rest of the items in the platter (the hummus and the morroccan salad) were still very good but the chicken was really disappointing. I'm hoping it was just a bad day and the next time I go there it will be better. I will keep you guys updated.
author: Isaw W.

description:
I went to the cave for the first time last night - surprising since I live right around the corner. But without getting into the why's and WTF's of that, I'd like to tell you about the inexplicable wait and terrible food.

The man behind the counter was really very nice to me. I will admit that not being familiar with the menu, and being awfully hungry, I was in a rush to order the first thing that came to mind. After having a delicious lamb kebab down the street earlier in the week, I was craving something similar, though now I realize I should have gone for the falafel.

He told me it would take 15 minutes to cook the lamb. OK, sure, no prob. I didn't think that kind of a wait sounded too terrible, considering it was the first time all day I'd had to relax and have some "me and my iphone" time.

45 minutes later I wasn't so thrilled. About 10 different people came in and stayed no longer than 10 minutes for their food. Granted, they were ordering falafel, but really - what kind of lamb had I ordered? Did they actually have to raise and slaughter the poor dear in the back? They guy was being really nice about it and I didn't complain, but inside my blood was boiling.

I finally got the effin lamb kebab in a wrap, took it home and expected to savor the most delicious lamb I'd ever had in my life, in front of my beloved TV with yet another HORRIBLE episode of Heroes - wtf are they doing with that show?

To the point: the food was terrible. I couldn't finish it, rather I didn't want to finish it. The lamb was dry and extremely tough, with peppers that burned my lips. Too many onions - I really thought for a second I had ordered the onion wrap.

I want to go back and try the falafel. It did look delicious.
author: Zara E.

description:
Just got the lamb plate with side of fries and tahini for about ten bucks and ate the whole thing in one sitting. It took about an hour and a half to finish and will definitely require some pant adjusting. I don't recommend the fries as a side- it's was overcooked, soggy and oily. it's usually one of the ingredients in the wrap and it's better that way.

My usual is the falafel and the lamb schwerma which are both really good and hella filling (yes I'm from the Bay Area). The falafel is spicy and the lamb is good quality meat. 

If you're jonesing for a baklava, theirs is pretty good albeit expensive ($2 for a small serving). It's light, flaky and not too sweet. Very flavorful. Yum.
author: None o.

description:
Ah....

This is the bEST falfel, shwarma in the country!

Take a look at the details in the falafel. Check out how beautiful the combination of potato and onions and shwarma come together like a well planned social gathering where concerned citizens come together to challenge the idiotic autocracy that still makes Tibetans homeless. 

Yes! Ali Baba's Cave is that place that understands the beautiful balance between tahini and falafel. As the great TV character from my childhood once said, "Don't drown your food in Mayo, Ketchup or Tahini!" 

It is so hard for me to remain focus because of the power of the food here.

What I love to do is get a falafel sandwich to go, walk down to the Women's building and look at the glorious image of Rigoberta Menchu.

That's right  two great icons of the world reside in San Francisco: Ali Baba's Cave and Rigoberta Menchu!

Que Viva Rigoberta! Que Viva Ali Baba!
author: mero cocinero k.

description: I ate here once. The falafel was awful. It was between room temperature and cold. I think they bought the grape leaves from Costco because I bought the same ones and I think they are made in China. The hummus was gross. The only decent item in the platter was the tabbouleh. They do have a lot of vegan and vegetarian options. But I can not recommend this place to anyone.
author: Philip R.

description: I almost always grab food here to take home, so I can't say much about the dine-in experience.  As far as the food is concerned, I think it's consistently good.  I have had the falafel sandwich dozens of times, and it is yummy - it's huge and has a lot of flavor.  I recently tried the meza platter, in which I chose three different items, and that was good too -- hummus, yogurt/cucumber salad and dolmas, and it came with some pita bread, so it was a pretty good meal.  Lots of good choices for vegetarians.  I'll be going back at least once a month.
author: Molly P.

description:
Update:  Why do I ever come to this one?  I always leave disappointed.  This location never even comes close to satisfying my Shawerma cravings... It's all about the Haight St version.

Old Review:
Nicer, cleaner and the same basic foods as the other Ali Baba's on Haight.  I think the food at the Haight one is better, but I prefer the atmosphere at this one.
author: Heidi P.

description: Lamb shwaerma wrap. Delicious and tender, all the things i enjoy about lamb in a huge phallic delight. I was very hungry when I ate here, so I had no problem finishing it all. On a regular day it might have been too many inches worth, I couldn't have taken it all. Sploosh, and the yogurt sauce was all over my face at the end.
author: Brad W.

description:
What can you say about AB except that it's a real solid performer. I've been there a handful of times and have never been dissapointed. That said, I've never been super impressed either. I like the idea of falafel on flat bread rolled but I must say that I've been spoiled by great falafel joints in the past. If you really know your falafel then I'll say that this place is no Mamouns and leave it at that. Don't read too much into that though... I don't think anyone can even come close to touching Mamouns so maybe that's an unfair comparison. 

ask for extra hot sauce.
author: Dan C.

description:
There was a time when this was a decent falafel place but that time has come and gone.  Now, not so much.  Their shwermas have always been decent but their falafels have always been as Brother Julian noted, mediocre.  I was there a couple day ago after not going for a while and the falafel wrap was barely fucking tolerable.  The one novelty of  Ali Baba's Cave was the large portions but when the food sucks its more like a trial by ordeal.  I've never liked the wraps they use taste like paper and the falafels have the personality of a #2 pencil.  The only reason why I ate most of it is that I am too cheap to waste it.  Their customer service reminds me of a Foreigner song, you know the one about being as cold as ice.  As for the establishment's cleanliness, 2 words: fly colony.

CONCLUSION: GO TO TRULY MED
author: ray M.

description:
Super reasonable and excellent value.

Great little hole in the wall.
author: E C.

description: Great falafel. Huge huge servings. Reasonably priced. I always ask for no french fries in mine, as they usually are cold, but everything else in this wrap will give you a good punch of what you're looking for. It doesnt matter who makes it (they don't always seem to care that you're there ordering food), its going to taste great. Haven't tried any other location, but can say this location is a great place for some Middle Eastern street food.
author: Daniel P.

description: Great food, big portions and authentic!  We arrived right when they opened a few Sundays go, so we had the place to ourselves for most of the meal.  4 people shared 3 plates and we were all stuffed.  Parking was super challenging, but that is expected in the city.
author: Hope W.

description: Much cleaner/nicer than the Haight location. Still great delicious food at low prices and big portions.
author: Mark A.

description:
awesome lamb shawarma, they know hot sauce.
The slender boy behind the counter is very friendly.

Every time i go, i want to throw away the cushions from the tent-looking area and rebuild it myself with some fresh ones, that'd the cherry on the cake, i mean, like fresh mint in a glass of tea! :)
author: Damien J.

description:
Great portion to price ratio, but I'm way more interested in this equation:

Flies + Food = Fail.

I would hate to eat at the home of anyone who gave this place a 5 star rating - their standards for cleanliness must be on some Grey Gardens shit.
author: Jay S.

description:
Ali Baba's Cave is an often visited restaurant for me and my boyfriend. 
The wraps are amazing and a very good size. The people who work there are just as awesome.
 My boyfriend went in the other night to pick us up some yummy wraps for dinner and paid with a 50$. Not thinking, cause we always get the correct change back, he walked out and came back home. We enjoyed our falafal wraps and it wasn't until the next morning that he realized he had received the wrong change. He called Baba's Cave and went in that day and they gave him back the correct change! Phew! So this place not only has great and filling food, it has great and honest people as well. I definitely give Baba's Cave five stars with no doubt. As for the rats, come on people...you're in the Mission.
author: Serena R.

description:
My new favorite cheap spot in the mission!  Great portions, excellent hummus, and really cheap.  After my first experience, I went back for side orders to-go. Huge!  Everyone at the vegan dinner was happy!
The decor could use some help and a good scrubbing, but forgotten when there's delicious falafel in front of you.
author: D. A.

description:
this was my first time trying a falafel of any kind and i would to have to say it's really not for me.  

i do like the idea of putting potato wedges into a "mediterranean burrito" but i was not feeling the hummus.
author: Cedric F.

description:
Walked into this place after heading to a Thai place, but got hungry and the group I was with decided we wanted shawarma instead.  Also, my brother's name is Ali so my friend though it would be humorous since I had just mentioned him.  Wee had the luxury of being able to sit in the small "cave", so it was quite a neat experience. 

The main attraction here is there shawarma sandwich made with a large lavash bread, resulting in a large wrap the size of a Chipotle burrito.  THIS WAS AWESOME.  I've never seen shawarma done like this, so my hungry belly was quite enthused.

I think the whole Chipotle-ness of it could be worked better and they could adopt the assembly line format where you get to pick your ingredients rather than a bunch of premade mishmashes (the toppings were scooped from containers, anyways).  Absolutely loved the fact that they put the fries IN THE SANDWICH, which was amazing.

I got the Ali Baba Special ($7.50), which was well worth the price.  It was stuffed with chicken, turkey, grilled veggies, and FRENCH FRIES.  That's right, they put the fries in the sandwich which was definitely the coolest thing about this place.  Amazing street food convenience. 

The toppings were a bit soggy, though, and the meat, well, a little dry and bland.  Kind of wish the sauce was less water and had a bit more flavor too it as well.   My whole sandwich ended up falling apart, which sucked, but I mean I still ate it all.  Could have easily split this into two meals but I'm a beast like that.  

This place is definitely worth trying but I won't be back too many more times unless they make some changes.  Follow the Chipotle model for a big-ass shawarma with fresher ingredients, more customization, and less shiesty service and this place could be a real trend-setting winner.  Matter fact, I think I have an idea....
author: Ibrahim M.

description:
Looking for a casual place to grab something delicious, yet affordable? Then go to Ali Baba's and order the Super Falafel!! This is the BEST falafel I have ever had -- I have had falafels all over the world, including Turkey. For $6 you get a delicious, fresh, dynamic falafel - and they do not hold back - they are huge, filling, and comforting. 

When in the Mission, I take all my friend to Ali Baba's for the Super Falafel and I have never had a complaint, rather, only praises.
author: Kaitlyn G.

description:
Okay, what motherfucking genius/saint thought it smart to grind, spice and fry chick peas into little fried balls of perfection?  i'd like to shake that man's hand and then possibly simulate oral sex on his fingers.  was this man jesus himself?  i'm not one to speculate on whether or not jesus invented falafel balls but whoever did most likely can do other crazy shit like turn water into wine and start enormous holy wars based strictly on the debate of his existence.  to you, sir, i say, BRAVO.  i also say, PEACE IN THE MIDDLE EAST!!!!!

the falafel at ali baba's cave is really very yummy and you can add fried eggplant and fried potatoes and fuck if that isn't the trifecta of fried deliciousness.  however, i'm gonna be forced to take one demerit point because these fools NEVER listen to you and i think it's worse if you're a woman.  listen, i understand that i am the weaker and stupider sex*, but if I say no fucking hot sauce, I mean no fucking hot sauce this whitey will DIE.  and i know you don't value my life because I am a woman but um, i don't know what to say.  i really have no ground to stand on when who i fundamentally am is a second class citizen at best and a wretched, whiny, bleeding, nagging, hooker beast at worst.  What can you do?  the falafel is really good.  it's so good in fact that the other night i exited Ali Baba's Cave on a complete falafel cloud of happiness.  I was so excited and happy about everything that I yelled, "cute dog!" to a super cute guy and his super cute dog as they drove by.  the guy gave me a puzzled look and as he rounded the corner, i noticed that what i saw in the back seat was not, in fact, a dog but rather, a very old and very short lady with curly white hair.  presumably his grandmother.  i am an asshole.  also, this falafel?  possibly magical as it creates illusions of the eye.  also, i am an asshole.

*This is a proven fact. Please don't argue with me about "Right to Vote" and "Able to Show Face Flesh in Public", Lucy Liberal and Esther Equality.  Just get back in the kitchen and finish my pot pie, bitches!  And if you forget the carrots like last time, there will be hell to pay.  Fool me once, shame on you.  Fool me twice, I will murder your whole family.
author: Laura B.

description: fine but not great. got a falafel sandwich. probably won't be going back. pretty bland and dry.
author: Tiana D.

description:
i just ate here today and i couldnt wait to rate them on yelp..

i came here at night around 8.30pm and i already know what i want to order in mind.. i wanted a shawarma.

i couldnt wait to rate the service so here it is. there was a white lady who ordered right in front of us and she got greeted, smiled and treated very very well, she was even greeted again and was said thank you on her way out. then i was the next in line,  i smiled and this lady who takes ur orders didnt even smile back... and i told her to go easy on the hot sauce and didnt even nod or respond that she got the message that i want to convey.. 

then i came to the cashier who wasnt looking in my eye, didnt even greet, didnt ask if i wanted a drink, his face looks disappointed, like he doesnt want to work there and i felt like he was thinking something bad against me..

my friend and i sat and waited for our orders. then came this lady who took our orders and blatantly put our orders on the table without even saying a word.. while we were there eating they decided that they wanted to have a conversation.. a very loud one.. and their voices are just hovering inside the place and my friend and i cant even focus on our conversation.. they no manners at all.. the service was so horrible that i didnt enjoy my food. the reason why is also because they didnt serve me well and they served the white people well.. hmmmm 

the food tasted blah and now i do agree that their food makes u sick because i feel  like throwing up right now..

on our way out my friend said thank you to them and yet again they didnt even say anything or make any gestures that they appreciate cutomers that come in their place.. so i came back and took the tip that we left for them simply because they didnt earn it..

thus i gave them 1 star..

so if ur hungry at night and ur not white and u dont wanna get sick? AVOID this place!! did i mention that the cashier's tshirt and hands are dirty?? ewww!

i encourage yelpers who were treated badly here to post their thoughts.
author: Naff Z.

description:
before i drop lots of money to amoeba's vinyl offerings, my stomach needs to be satisfied first and foremost.  this place comes highly recommended by a person of interest so, you know what's next.  

i gets, she gets, a falafel sandwich which we demolished  at 4pm with taste buds in complete euphoria.  i'm still full over 7 hours later - perfect timing for me to wind it up on de dancefloor at agenda, reggae dancehall in my ears and mediterranean in my body...

i'll have to try this spot again next time i'm in the neighborhood.
author: watani f.

description: This Ali Baba's Cave is the one to go to.  Good selection of other items outside of the Falafels and swarmas, but you might want to avoid the huge rice pastry ball that stuffed with lamb meat.  It was kinda weird and had a strong cinnamon taste.  The chicken swarma is good because I like it spicy.  Weaklings that can't handle the heat better ask for no spicy paste!  Friendly and good servings.   Don't go to the Haight location!
author: Jason A.

description: This place has the best falafel I've ever eaten, and I fancy myself a bit of a falafel connoisseur at this point.  If you like falafel, check Ali Baba's out!
author: Michael D.

description: This place is alright. I used to live across the street and found myself getting takeout when I was too lazy or too indecisive to do anything else. I certainly don't find myself craving it now that I'm no longer in the neighborhood though. Bonus points for cooking everything to order.
author: Ben E.

description: I love this place! Lamb Shawarma is sooo gooood! Great place to get a quick, inexpensive, bite to eat. The staff is very friendly.
author: Brad N.

description: My most favorite place for falafel in the city! I can get at least 2-3 meals out of any of their selections because they are huge, particularly the sandwiches. Though I usually opt for any of several vegetarian combo platters. I love the lentil rice too. It makes the rice at Zain's look like it should be lining a hamster cage. I don't think there's much else to say. Who gets falafel for the atmosphere?
author: Sharon T.

description: The wraps here are really tasty, definitely fill me up. Just go to the counter, decide if you want turkey, lamb, or falafel and they'll make it and bring it to your table (or you can take it to go). It's sort of like a middle easter/mediterranean burrito :) I like the yogurt sauce, and I REALLY like the spicy sauce. The french fries/potatoes in the wrap are a nice surprise. I've also had the side of eggplant, and loved it!
author: Kristy C.

description: One of my top late-night picks for quick, cheap delicious Middle Eastern.  I usually get the chicken shawarma, which is extremely tasty (and enormous - I usually only eat half of it in a sitting), but I've also had the veggie plate and don't remember having any complaints about it.  Ali Baba's shawarma's are just further evidence that one of God's greatest gifts to us is food in tube form.
author: Angela B.

description: Having been all over the place, even to the hallowed L'As du Falafel shop in Paris where Lenny Kravitz is said to have frequented, I have never found a place for shawerma and falafel like this one.  The building itself and its insides are irrelevant - it's the food that counts.  If you're squeamish about old tables and dirty floors just get take-out.  I haven't been able to find such tasty mediterranean food anywhere.
author: Scott S.

description:
incredibly large portions, the vegetarian plate was more than i could handle. 

really tasty
really friendly

oh and the falafel sandwich comes with french fries inside
nuff said
author: Chris G.

description:
sort of feel weird now that I read about all the critters, 'cause yeah, I did have to bus my own table and it didn't strike me as the cleanest place evah. but then, I was after fast food and not fine dining. 

get the dang falafel wrap without the fried potatoes and you will be so much more happy. they are the reason for the antacid. I liked the hot sauce, it had good heat. it will not be the reason. the eggplant is way overcooked in my opinion, but it does add a pleasing babagounesh flavor to the wrap.

my standards are way more flexible these days. after actually FINDING a cockroach in my food in Bali, Indonesia, everything is cake now. i thought the food was tasty and filling and I was able to share one falafel wrap with a friend and walk away satisfied. cheap too.

so, I can recommend with a caveat. don't look, just eat.
author: Miel H.

description: Falafel wrap is a must , i hear great things about the lamb wrap as well, inexpensive and easily spit amongst two. ( i couldn't  finish mine), im a fan of spicy food , but just a small amount their hot sauce was enough. yay i'm a fan
author: Wei W.

description:
falafel wrap. drool.

by far my most fav falafel wrap. i make a point to visit ali baba's at least once everytime i'm the s.f. the thing is massive and stuffed with goodies like eggplant, fries, parsley, cucumber yogurt, etc. though they did raise the price most def is worth you wild. agian, my 2 cents
author: Randall P.

description: its great, i love it. HUGE falafel wrap for a great price. all other dishes are good too. It's definitely worth trying.
author: Tim R.

description: Falafel good, a bit pricey, comfy, I sat next to a lamp.
author: Mark G.

description:
i used to love this place..................until a giant fucking rat came out of the "cave" and stared me in the eyes.


never again. never ever ever.
author: Ginny M.

description: This restaurant is sooooo good I enjoyed their hummus very much. The food there was very fresh and moderately priced. YUMMY!
author: Johanna T.

description: LOVE LOVE LOVE!! OK. So the ambience isnt great, but the food will make up for the lack of pizzaz in the restaurant. It is difficult to find GOOD vegetarian falafels in SF, but Ali Baba's cave is amazing. PS, one falafel is enough for 2 people. ENJOY!
author: Arti D.

description: As far as I'm concerned they make the best Falafel sandwich in town. Certainly the best I've ever tasted and the kicker is it's huge (the sandwich that is).  Spicy! You know it's good when you're sitting there with three friends and no one exchanges a word for the half hour it takes to slowly savor this monster. 5 stars!
author: Mingus R.

description: Oh hell yeah.  This place is open til midnight and it's nice and filling.  They make their wraps european style with the french fries inside.  Drool.
author: angela k.

description: Best falaffal in town! Very affordable and large portions! Deeeeelicious!!!!
author: Brittany B.

description: Just had my first falafel in a long time here. As a buritto addict, I liked that it looked like a buritto and was as big as one, but it was definitely a nice alternative to my traditional Mission fare. My wrap was nice and crispy with eggplant, falafel, taters and whatever tasty sauce they put in there. Hey, I'm your average white kid so I'm not up on all the hip, Mediterranean ingredients, but damn it was good. And huge. I just ate the other half for lunch today and wow, it's just as good cold. When I make the return trip I'll have to try the shawarma and hang out in their cool little cave.
author: Michael E.

description: Lamb shawarma spicy is great great stuff, I second whoever recommended that.  This is a GREAT place.  Good food, reasonable prices, huge portions.  The service however is really atrocious - I've waited 45 minutes for my food before, I've called in orders to find they weren't made 30 minutes later, I've gotten every confusing answer I could have hoped for from the staff. I keep going back because it is good, but I wish the staff would magically change/disappear, possibly into the staff from Zane's on 24th.
author: Tyler W.

description: Best shawarma wrap I've had in quite a long time, seriously. It was also free, which made it taste just that much better.  The fact that they put french fry type things into it just adds to the overall delectability of the sandwiches. Make sure you call ahead as it can sometimes take a long time to get your food, especially if they're busy!
author: Craig E.

description: Don't be too hard on this place.  After wandering around the Pirate supply store/McSweeney's, and Paxton Gate, you'll need a cheap and easy place to eat.  If you get there early, steal the small floor-pillow covered room with a group of 2-4 or so friends.  It's a cheap way to be romantic.  Their falafel is good and the other things that I've had have been good as well.  Not the friendliest of service, but if you like a little side of abuse with your meal, it's worth it.
author: Shelley T.

description: I don't care what anyone says. I love Ali Baba's Cave. I get the shawerma every time and I think it is the perfect harmony of all the different tastes. The falafel is also perfect (its actually moist and slightly crispy on the outside!). The guy who owns it is also really friendly and treats people like family when he is there.
author: Prasant R.

description: I'm no Mediterranean food guru but they easily have the best falafel wrap I've ever tasted.  It's huge and I couldn't believe how much they packed into it for only $6.  Before they started making it, I was salivating over the homemade french fries and potatoes, wishing I could afford to get  a side of each... little did I know I'd automatically get BOTH inside the wrap!  Be sure to order the "super" version which includes their amazing, savory grilled eggplant for 50 more cents. A+!!!
author: Laurel O.

description: At this point, Ali Baba's has the top chicken shawarma wrap that I have had in the city.  It is enough for two people and I am a fat ass.  They put some cottage fries and fried eggplant inside along with some hot sauce...it is f-ing awesome.   You are in for a treat if the old man is behind the counter. The wraps have been a bit on the dry side lately and that translates into a big mess once you settle in.  Be careful, DO NOT UNWRAP the shawarma more than what is necessary to bite into it...otherwise you better get yourself a fist full of napkins and a fork.
author: Jason G.

description:
Judging from some of the other Yelp! reviews, this restaurant has some sanitary/cleaning issues.  Here's my story.

In December 2008 I brought my out-of-town brother and a friend of his to experience some falafel and shwarma.  I ordered my falafel first and am sure glad I did.  After the gentleman behind the counter made my wrap, he proceeded to replace the shwarmas behind him with new ones.  Then he made my brother's, and his friend's, wrap.

The problem here?  He replaced the cooked chicken with raw chicken WITH HIS BARE HANDS and then proceeded to touch, with those hands, every single ingredient that went into my brother's wrap.  There was no hand washing, sanitizing, or even wiping them on a towel.

Although we watched this with horror, we didn't speak up.  My brother and his friend ate their shwarmas and miraculously didn't get sick afterwards.  Although I had a vegetarian dish, it seems quite likely that raw chicken was probably on the cook's hands before he made mine.  

Therefore, I will never return to any Ali Baba's again.  Although you get a lot of food for a good price, the sanitary issues with this establishment just aren't worth it.  Try Truly Mediterranean instead.  So far, they've washed their hands after touching raw meat.
author: Joanne G.

description:
falafel wrap/sandwich is amazing.

best deal in all of SF

5 bucks for the most amazing food ever wrapped into something the size of your forearm.

tahina and hot sauce are vegan.
author: Alex F.

description:
Dono makes me go here because the portions are HUGE and cheap.

I loathe the idea of going here, since the Cave recently gave me the worst stomach ache of my life. 

Also, the service is incredibly lackluster. Don't bother leaving a tip, since they don't bother bringing you utensils.
author: Mia L.

description:
This place is pretty good though it does need to be cleaned and painted. We went in the expectation that the food was good, but don't expect much in the way of decor. Also, don't wear your nice clothes. 

So if you can get over those things you'll get a great large falafel for cheap and have a good experience.

If you need some caffeine because the coffee machine is broken, go across the street to the bubble tea shop and get one to go. Try it with the tapioca balls and large straws. 

This would be 5 stars since it's tasty and cheap but -1 star for neglect of the interior and slightly absent service.
author: John W.

description: Pretty darn good falafel (I consider myself a pro with this stuff), huge portions, and stuffed with eggplant as well as potatoes.
author: Tamar N.

description: This used to be one of my favorite places to grab a quick, cheap dinner or lunch usually in the form of their delectable lamb shawerma. Recently, I went to Ali Baba's with my boyfriend and were upset to see that the whole staff had changed. They gave our orders to someone else and when we asked them where our food was, I was basically told to shut up. Never going there again. A total shame because that shawerma was amazing.
author: Maria D.

description: The falafel sandwich was huge and delicious! And on lavash, which I love. Good value for what you get. However, my boyfriend got some sort of round phyllo and sesame covered ball and it was not good at all. Get the falafel, but I can't vouch for anything else.
author: Rachel P.

description: Someone suggested this place to my hubby, claiming that they have the best falafel in the city. Not so sure about that -- the falafel was a little too salty for my taste -- but what a huge bargain. Got a falafel platter with salad, hummus, tabbouleh and pita for six bucks, and hubby's giant shawerma wrap was bigger than my head and approx. the same price. Quite a steal.
author: Beth T.

description: The tabouli is pretty good. They also have some unique dishes like this big shell stuffed with basmati rice and lamb. Kind of quiet and a nice change of pace from Truly Mediterranean.
author: Peter S.

description: Best middle-eastern quick food in SF. Huge falafel sandwiches are good for two meals, and cost less than other places, and also include potatoes and eggplant for no extra charge. I don't know if it still is but it was BYO. Sit in the alcove on the nasty pillows and enjoy. The credit card machine is funky and takes some time to dial up. Also there is ice water in the fridge in a huge pitcher.
author: matt c.

description: I think it can be difficult to judge the objective authenticity of a broad-reaching cuisine like "middle eastern", but for what it's worth this is about the only place my friend from Jerusalem would go for shawarma in SF. As others have mentioned, ask for it spicy.. assuming, of course, that you enjoy pain.
author: erik h.

description: I love a good falafel and shewarma, plus prices can't be beat here.  The high turnover with staff here is what's questionable, last time I had a Korean woman making a me a shewarma, so consistency or lack of consistency could be a bit off of your expectations here.
author: B H.

description:
mmmm  this place is soo good.

the falafel sandwich is amazing here! It's huge and cheap and you can split it with someone.. unless your boyfriend is being a big pig and insists that he have his own.. only to stop eating halfway through because .. he's full.. mmhmm

i would give them 5 stars but when they say cave.. they really mean cave. the place does not appear to be very clean.. which makes me uncomfortable. but hells.. the food is good.

don't order the eggplant by itself unless you want a platter of cold grease
just a few pieces in the falafel sandwich is great though

did i mention the baklava? oh yes.. diet destroying bastards...
author: Amber F.

description: I had the vegetarian combo dish and while the lentils and the hummus were pretty good and definitely edible, I could not get anywhere near the tabouli.  Too many onions! Whew!
author: Joanna S.

description: Please clean the cave before serving food here! I was totally sketched out by guy making falafel sandwiches here. He used his bare hands to plop four falafel balls into our sandwiches.  Then he took our cash, gave change, and proceeded on to make the next sandwich without washing his hands in between.  We took our sandwiches to the dirty table area and picked the one with the least amount of crumbs and sat down on faded, greasy looking benches.  The sandwiches were very good and included onions, french fries, eggplant, yummy yogurt and hummus sauces.  The bread was thin and crispy, not doughy like street fair falafels usually are. They were also very large, about a foot long.  All in all, yummy food but couldn't fully enjoy due to the health code violations all around me.
author: Julie D.

description: Everyone.....Today I had my first taste of Turkey Schwarma in the states, well Turkey Schwarma in any STATE. The taste=Good The Look=Good The Deliciousness=Good The After Math= MUDBUTT.   Worth it? Yes, Fuck yes. I cant remember any negative experience, in fact most good experiences included at least a Schwarma and or a Doner Kebab. I recommend, considering i have seen this place for years and only today did i choose to risk a few bucks. The service is a bit lax, expect to repeat your order to at least 2 people and it will get done eventually. Make Love and Schwarma.
author: Joe J.

description: I bet a friend a falafel sandwich at Truly Med against the Ali Baba's falafel sandwich.  I lost the bet.  But in such a bet, there can be no loser, and now I gladly walk the extra two blocks for this truly superior food item.  I usually don't even like eggplant.
author: Kasey K.

description: Huge Shawermas, but definitely not a first meal after fasting all week (unless you like donating half of it to the trees out front). Full of flavor and indigestion. Try Truly Med. at 16th and Valencia, I'm addicted.
author: Charles W.

description:
Cave Dwellers I have the hardest time leaving a job. I always think that if I just stick it out things will get better. I been pounding away @ the Guardian for about nine months, I sold some ads and learned alot about selling and how I communicate w/ people. I just wonder if I was set up to fail. My boss plays favorites. M gets all the attention and plenty of hand holding in her sales. M (male) gets to dick her down (My boss @ the Guardian is sleeping w/ her employee and has the nerve to bring up professionalism???)and get plenty of hand holding in sales. I ask her to go to a meeting w/ me and she cancelled just hours before. Not that its that big a deal just that it lets you kno' where you stand in the grand skeem of things. I mean should I be mad if she can go out and court other clients till the weee hours of the night but she can't even remember that I have a meeting. No. I should just move on. So I'm off. Took my last Guardian lunch @ Ali BaBa's cave. Waiting for my chicken kaboba (takes 15mins) I had time think if I had made the right move. I did. I feel better today than I have in some time. No need to worry the cave dwellers. They would be w/ out the token black guy to kick around.

All names have been changed to protect the friends, fiends, innocent, guilty, stupid, crazy and down right bad. I also reserve the right to miss spell, phonetically spell and use bad grammar where needed.
author: Friday L.

description: I get take out from here twice a week....it's great.  I like the chicken shwarma wrap[get it with eggplant] and the hummus.  Its some of the best hummus I've had.
author: Rob P.

description: Theirs is the best Falafel sandwich I've had in SF. The sandwich includes Hummus, Hot sauce, French Fries, Eggplant, Falafel and some potato and peas salad. A weird combination, but it works very well surprisingly. And to top it off, their hot sauce is actually pretty hot, which is a huge plus in my book. The place is a little run down, but hey you can't beat their prices. $ 5.95 for a sandwich which could feed two after tax is a pretty sweet deal.
author: Tushar V.

description: Huge falafel wraps with all sorts of yummy stuff in there.  Friendly staff, nice place to sit and eat.
author: Aimee B.

description: Ali Baba is famous for their rotiserrie chicken, Ali Baba salad, tabbouli and hummus.  Everything is pretty good and authentic here...even a Middle Eastern acquaintance of mine have told me this. I have, on a few occasions, ordered their chicken and it was a little dry so I give it 4 stars only. If you are nearby, they have free delivery for orders over $50.  The restaurant is also beautifully remodeled with a Mid East touch.
author: Stephanie L.

description: My favorite place for a falafel in San Francisco. So ok, the decor it terrible and the lighting is obnoxious but who can complain when the food is this good. The baba ganouche is smokey, the madjadarra all earthy  and subtly sweet from the caramelized onions, and the tabboule is lemony and fresh. I'm addicted to the  Baklava.
author: Stellah D.

description: Great, massive, tasty shawerma and falafel sandwiches, also with platter options. Simple menu, and while you can dine in, it's definately a Mediterranean fast-food sort of place. But damn good.
author: Don H.

description: Really really good and huge falafel sandwiches, quite the bargain.  Great for a quick and easy bite but lacks any sort of ambiance, the bathroom was disturbing...but who cares, the food is good.
author: Debbie Y.

description: Best place to get a falafel sandwich in the Mission. Much better than Truly Mediterranean. I always ask them to heat my sandwich longer than usual. It comes out much better that way.
author: Paul W.

description: When I first moved to SF I would drive everyday from the far side of potrero to come to Ali Baba's Cave on Valencia for their falafel sandwich.  I'm still not tired of the place after 6 years. It's one of my favorite  falafel joints in the city. I haven't tried the meat dishes ie shwarma etc but I hands down recommend trying this place. They also have a cool little "cave" nook if you want the full arabian experience.
author: Phil M.

description:
tasty neighborhood place for shawermas... and other combo plates...
authentic?  probably as authentic as burrito places are to mexican food...
but gosh darn tasty...
author: charlotte s.

description: Really great falafel (but the other food is somwhat questionable),  nice service,  and a place to sit down and eat. good stuff.
author: Matt G.

description: Came here, and I agree with some of the other reviewers...it's nothing to go home and write an e-mail to your folks about.  I still prefer Truly Mediterranean over on 16th, but it's probably because the service over there was so homey.
author: Mark D.

description: I like Ali Baba's.  The portions are ginormous.  It is more than you might expect but you get a lot for what you are putting on the table.  I order a chicken shiskabab but it is either two meals or I share with a friend.
author: Jaime Patricio M.

description: I really like the burrito style falafels here and it is incredibly tasty. it is also cheaper than truly meditarranean :).
author: Anthony K.

description: They serve HUGE portions here, next time we will split a plate. I didn't even eat half of what they gave me. Cheep prices and they do have a cool cave booth seat-style area. You may have to time it just right to get a seat in there but, it's comfy and fun. They have good tunes, real loud. So, the falafel was yummy, they are big and the hummus was really good. I am a fan and will be back. Quick service too!
author: Heather L.

description: offers reasonably priced, proportionally large, adequately fresh meals and accommodating, extensive seating, with one seating area in cave-like recessed area, just as the moniker suggests
author: ben r.

description:
Ali Baba's a great place to go to get lots of tasty food if you're on a budget. The decor is decent, mostly what you expect from a hole in a wall kind of joint, simple tables and chairs. What is really nice is that they have this little cove, with throw pillows, curtains, where you're seated on the floor. It's a fun little sanctuary.

My favorite thing to order is the falafel sandwich. Instead of pita, they use lavash, creating a huge, long burrito-like wrap. In addition to the typicla hummus, and tahini sauce, they also add french fries and eggplant to it to make a really robust, tasty meal. Definitely at least two meals worth of food, but hey, leftovers make for the best midnight snacks.
author: Anh-Thu N.

description: This places makes me sad. When I moved to SF, I had had the lamb shwarma here my very first night and loved it. I've been back a dozen times or so and something happened, the quality is way down. The wraps I used to crave aren't good. I didn't even finish my last one. They also switched from wrapping them in foil to wax paper, so they fall apart and drip mid way through. Such a disappointment.
author: Julia W.

description: I was with Theodore O. when we saw bugs (cockroaches!) at this place. It was quite depressing, as the food was otherwise pretty good. I can't tolerate cockroaches at BOTH caves (in the mission and on haight!) Filth is the one thing that is intolerable in a restaurant..after that it was all over.
author: Peter F.

description:
I was there this past weekend. We were the first to get in that day. The food is very tasty (at least the humus was). I ordered the shawarma plate and my date ordered the falafel plate. There are a few things that i peeved me so I took off some points


1) The proprietor used his bare hands to pick up the falafel and the lavash bread. If that doesnt kill your appetite then good for you.

2) My date said she thought the falafel were stale and seemed like had been refried a few times. I didnt eat them, but she has frequented MANY greek restaurants in chicago so I trust her judgement. She hardly ate anything and refused to take the stuff with her to eat later. She must have not liked hwe food at all.

3) The interior is really unkempt.
author: nik s.

description: Nothing to write home about but in a pinch, will do. The falafel sandwich is OK, but I've had better. The chicken shawarma was dry and too much oregano, or some unknown herb!
author: Reza E.

description: Great falafel for a great price. Sure the fries are cold, but it didnt take away from the delicious sandwich. A different taste to the Mission's typical Mexican food.
author: Richard G.

description: They say that this is the best falafel sandwich in the city and although it was my first time having a falafel sandwich, it was very tasty. It is one intense experience complete with french fries inside the sandwich. The sandwich is huge and was definitely a two day meal.
author: Erin O.

description: What a yummy place with friendly service. It's a cafeteria style restaurant with really good food. The portions are big and there are a lot of choices. I had the lamb shawerma and my boyfriend had the super popular falafel sandwich. Both were delicious. The shawerma was a lot spicier than I expected. The hummus and eggplant side dishes are AWESOME!!! We were disappointed by their baklava, but it's a causal and good restaurant.
author: Gladys C.

description: I was enticed by the huge mountain of fried aubergines sitting by the counter as I walked passed this place. I had a falafel sandwich, which consists of lavash topped with hummus, fried potatoes, fried aubergines and finally 4 giant falafels. Never saw a wrap so photogenic (and also delicious).
author: Mark C.

description: I've walked pass this place everytime I go to Dolores park. I was a little reluctant about coming in and trying the place out since their Health inspection card wasn't posted out the window. As soon as I came in the guy was very helpful about what was on their menu. I had lots of questions. Their Lamb kabobs are really really good, and I must say very filling. I came in the second time and tried their falafel sandwich and damn was I amazed! It was just the perfect combination of goodness. I didn't feel guilty about eating the whole thing. I finally saw the Health Inspection Score card, it wasn't too high but was still in the 90's. I still recommend the place but I gave it four stars rather than 5 due to the fact that you have to hunt down the Health Inspection Score Card.
author: Lucky M.

description:
I am a new yelper and i take my duties seriously.
The food is cheap and thats about it. There is nothing else worth mentioning. Do not order the phyllo dough bake filled with lamb, the spices were raw, the lamb full of fat, i couldn't eat it and i am one of those people who never waste food, no matter how bad. 

Skip the arabian coffee.
author: snigdha c.

description: I love the falafel sandwiches.  They are cheap and big enough for two meals.  You should go out of your way just to try one.  I'm serious.
author: Jenna M.

description: A more-than-decent "super" falafel that almost rivals--dare I say it--Truly Mediterranean.
author: Maximillian M.

description: Ask for your falafel sandwich "extra juicy" and grab a fistful of napkins, it's gonna be a wet ride.  The falafel sandwich is *huge* and once fed me for 2 days straight.  What you hear about the decor is true and the bathroom door no longer locks but, just take care of your business quickly or bring a friend and you'll be set.
author: Ky W.

description:
After reading the reviews here, I decided this would be the next stop on my quest for the city's best falafel.  And indeed, it was good.  They add an excellent spicy sauce to it, something I hadn't seen at good frikin chicken.  I think the falafel itself is actually slightly better at gfc/truly mediterranean, but the spice here was an excellent addition.

As far as cleanliness goes, from what I saw it wasn't the cleanest place in the world, but it definitely wasn't as bad as what I read in other reviews.  Think college dorm room.
author: John D.

description: some of the best chicken schwarma around. Comes with eggplant, hummus, fries!
author: Kelly H.

description: I'm totally craving this spot right now so it'll be my first review. Basically, I can't speak for the rest of the menu; my experience is limited to the falalel but why bother? The falafel is rolled up in a lavache wrap (not pita) and grilled. Also, it's like, a foot long, serious. Then it costs you less than 5 bucks. Crap. I am leaving immediately to go get one. I'm going to the Lower Haight joint.
author: Jenn W.

description: The schwerma wraps are divine.  They add french fries for a neat-o twist.  I have had the hummus, tahini sauce, chicken and falafel and they are all great.  Giant.  Cheap.  Fabulous.  Yum!
author: Valerie D.

description: The affordable lamb shawarma hits the spot every single time. Friendly staff too.
author: Marcia O.

description: Falafel wrap with eggplant is the bomb.  it's huge, it looks like a bomb or a fatty or a huge arm-sized taffy wrapped up. it's crunchy and saucy and veggi-ful.  you can mash it on your plate and eat it with fingers and forks or shove it in your mouth.  it's sooooooo good.
author: Today Y.

description: This wrap was really good. The chicken wrap was juicy and quite tasty, includes eggplant and fries, and for only 6 bucks. ambience is cute, very casual/informal. would recommend this place over truly mediterranean also in the mission.
author: Cooter Z.

description: The service here was really nice, very friendly, but the food was awful. I ordered a turkey wrap in lavosh and the turkey was dry and hard and flavorless. Could not finish it.
author: Eater S.

description: I'm partial to this place because it's comfort food but the vegetarian staples (falafel and hummus) are genuinely good. There's a lack of atmosphere, for sure, but it keeps the crowds at bay.
author: Selim N.

description: I have never had anything I like here and it always seems really dirty. Go to Truly Med instead. Much better.
author: Adrienne G.

description: Get yourself a Falafel Sandwich with everything split it in half,  because its so good its hard not to eat the whole thing.  Then smile to yourself cause its good good good, and its wicked cheap.
author: Ona E.

description:
Yes, yes and yeeeesss!!!!

If only the kebab sandwich did not take 30 minutes to be prepared and the wrap to be grilled, I would give them half a star more (not that you can, I don't think!).

If you are hungry, then you will start daydreaming of Ali Baba's cave. We were almost shaking when our wraps finally arrived at the table.
It was my first time there. But, I can tell you that I have craved the cave more than once since then...

Very friendly staff, too.
author: Nena G.

description: I would have given this place 3 stars for their great value but can you trust a place that puts fries in their sandwich yet refuses to mix shwarma with falafel?
author: Kurosh H.

description: love it , good food , place is a bit drity ,but good food
author: matt p.

description: I really love this place.  Just a little below "Med Wraps" in Palo Alto, but probably the best one I've had in the City.
author: Kryzak K.

description:
Was there on a Friday night for the first time. Ordered chicken shwarma. It had very strange taste, felt like indian curry mixed with mediterranean food. Couldn't eat any more than couple of bites. Complete waste of my pocket book.

Vowed myself never to step in there again. In order to recover myself, walked to the Bi-Rite and got one scoope of ice creame.
author: Ruben C.

description: Great deal for shawerma and falafel sandwiches.  Ideal for those looking for fast food with a Mediterranean/Middle Eastern flavor.  People looking for truly "authentic" Middle Eastern cuisine here, though, will probably be as satisfied as someone looking for "authentic" Central/South American cuisine at a local, hole-in-the-wall burrito and taco shop.
author: Rick E.

description: So if you're in the Mission and tired of having another burrito or taco, you gotta try this place.  Get the Lamb Shwamerma (Sp?) spicy, well that's how I like it, or if you can't handle the heat get it regular.  Tasty food and one spot that I frequent on a regular basis.
author: Bhavesh M.

description: Best Falafel Sandwich ever. I alway inhale it and then have realised I have over eaten and feel like pooh the rest of the day. It is soo good, this must be how people who live in excees of food feel. UMMM. If my stomach could have an orgasm it would be this.
author: Ryan O.

description:
I went there for lunch and it was horrible.
The chicken was half raw and half burned and they wrapped the paper inside the bread!!! That's the worst think you can do to Schawarma!
author: Zum Z.

description:
the falafel is very tasty and cheap.
the lamb shawerma is allright.
the seating cave in the back is pretty nifty.
the baklava is yummy.
they're open late.

i'm not so big on all the raw onions- i think next time i'll get the falafel sandwich without them.

overall a good cheap place to get lunch
author: Foo K.

description: They have great chicken and lamb shawarma for the price.  I have to admit you need to be careful when they ask you if you want eggplant and fries as extras because this will cost more then listed on the menu.  I go here after climbing at Mission Cliff at night but they sometimes close earlier then 11pm if traffic is slow.
author: J J.

description: I had a filling, cheap and delicious late lunch/early dinner here.  Atmosphere a little divey but not bad.  Pretty much no frills, chow and run.
author: Celeste A.

description:
Tried a falafel sandwich to go - not impressed. When asked 'with everything', I wasn't expecting to find chewy fries and charred eggplant in my sandwich. Nor was I expecting to be told that it was going to be 50 cent extra. When I said I wanted 'everything that is in a regular falafel sandwich', the answer was: 'the eggplant is already in it now'. Good thing someone else behind the bar told her to take the 50c off again. Didn't like the eggplant or the fries one bit though. And it's pretty dirty in there.
I hope I won't be served a falafel with whale meat and gold dust for $80 next time, I guess you never know what you get when you agree to everything.....
author: Victoria A.

description:
Yes, it is dirty, and yes, I have seen mice run by my feet on several occasions, but the falafels are so huge, cheap and awesome that I swallow my rodent fear for an evening. Its worth it, its not like you'll get the plague from eating there. 

I like the vegetarian shish kabob platter, but it takes a while for them to make, so only order it if you are comfortable sitting with the mice for an extra 15 minutes.
author: Nora Z.

description:
We were in a rush for some good take out and stumbled across this place, and I am very glad we did. We pick up a falafal and WOW, great flavor, huge quantity and one of the best falafal's i have eaten in a very very very long time. If you like spicy food, make sure you ask them to put more of their hot sauce, its yummy. 

Great food, cant wait to go back and eat some more.
author: amruta m.

description: I just threw away 3/4 of my lamb kebab, which was burnt and sloppily thrown together, because it was one of the worst things I've tasted in my entire life. On top of that, there were rats running around on the floor, and the service was extremely poor - a little love might have made me come back to try again, but when not a single element of service or tasty kebab comes my way, I have to warm others... eat at your own risk.
author: Andrew S.

description: Great food.  No frills.  Good portions for a fair price.
author: Gadget H.

description: Get a shawarma and sit where all the pillows and the low table are.
author: Erin S.

description: The falafel wrap with everything on it is spectacular....and is really really large so for me it's always 2 meals in 1 and the price is great.  I highly recommend trying it.
author: Hil O.

description: I cannot for the life of me understand how this place stays in business.  I will be fair and preface this by saying that I recently traveled in the Middle East, and I am comparing their food to the EXCELLENT falafel that I had there.  Still, this place's falafel is incredibly disappointing. How difficult is it to serve things in FRESH pita and how hard is it to actually sell FRESH falafel that is not tasteless and whose texture does not make it seem that it has been sitting there for several days!? Two last comments, also not positive - if you're watching your profit margin, just raise the price of your wraps a bit and don't nickel and dime people if they ask for a bit more hummus or something. Again, maybe I'm unfairly comparing them to the places I tried abroad but, come on, just give me some damn baba ganoush without informing me that it's 50 cents extra!  And, finally, the service here is terrible.  Allow me to dispel the belief, Ali Baba employees/owners: you are not doing ME a favor by serving me! In fact, I can only assume that your food is not at all fresh & is sitting out all day because your customer base is lacking!
author: SL N.

description: This place has been around for a while.  I prefer it to Truly Tasteless Mediterranean on 16th.  From other reviews, I don't think I'll be sitting in the "cave", but I'll keep going back for more falafel.
author: Lolee B.

description: I'm confused by all the bad reviews of this place. I've eaten here 20 times in the past year and it's consistently tasty.  Great lamb schwarma, real juicy, with great hot sauce.  Somebody below said it was "pricey" but I really don't think you can get this amount of good food, in the case of the lamb schwarma, for under $8 anywhere else!
author: Patrick W.

description:
It's been at least a year since I've eaten there, since I've been boycotting the place, so I can't speak to the food or their current practices, but as of about a year ago: they're awful business people and dishonest cheats.
They had a policy of essentially trying to rip off every customer of 50 cents to a dollar. I'm a mellow guy who let's mistakes happen, but when do the same thing repeatedly, it's simple dishonesty.
Here's how the scam works:
You ask for a falafel. There is no description anywhere on any menu of what comes on the falafel. They start to make it and ask you if you want fries and eggplant on it. You say sure. They hand you the falafel and ring you up at the cash register. Lo and behold, it's almost a dollar more than the printed price for a falafel. You say, "but the menu says $X.XX?" They say, "But you ordered a super." But I didn't order a super, and there isn't even a "super" on the damn menu! Of course, by that point, you feel that, well, they already made the thing and you don't want them to throw it away, so you just pay up and take it. Everyone just pays the extra rather than making a big deal about it, and these guys take in many extra bucks a day from chumps like us.

Well, this happened once. I went back a couple months later. Same thing happened. Then I was determined to give them one more chance to prove they weren't corrupt. I went back again a couple months later. I was very careful with what I said and explicit that I just wanted a plain falafel, just like it says on the menu. They never tell you that fries and eggplant cost extra (and it's not printed anywhere), they just non-chalantly ask you if you want some, as if it were a burrito place asking what kind of beans you want. It's fine to charge more for "extras." It's another to not disclose to people that these are extras and pretend they're not until you ring it up. Of course, the exact same thing happened. Not only that, but it was like $1.50 more this time. His explanation was that they didn't have the "current" increased prices on the menu board yet. I called him on it. He started raising his voice and saying that "no one else complains."
Well, everyone else isn't paying attention.
I hope they've mended their ways, but if they haven't, watch out and call them on it.
author: josh s.

description: Stopped by for  quick bite and got the lamb shawarma plate for 10 bucks. Its a ton of food- totally enough for two. I thought the hummus in particular was great. However, in the seating area there were some very dirty pillows that totally distracted me from enjoying the food. I've been here a couple of times and enjoyed the food every time but would really like them to clean the place up. The pillows weren't just a little dirty. They were filthy. Its hard to eat in an environment like that.
author: Colleen S.

description: decent but ginormous mediterranean wraps. falafel a little dry and addition of french fries a little weird. but i liked the dabs of hot sauce! my bite of bf's lamb schwarma pretty yummy tho.
author: Angi C.

description: I consider myself an expert at shwarma. Why? 'Cause when it's good, it's really damn good, and when it's bad, you get diarrhea. Ali's is really damn good. Ali also likes to keep his pita crispy. That, my cave-dwelling friend, is awesome.
author: Nick M.

description: this looks more like a take-out place when i visit then an actual dine-in. i guess ive never been there during dinner time! anyway, i love their delicious shwarma's. since i like it piping hot, they make sure i get it they way i like it! try the one with lamb - yummy!
author: Sha A.

description: Big. Hot. Nas-tay.  You excited yet?  Say what you will about this place, but the the falafel wrap is still one of my favorite grab and go food items in the city.  On the short list of food items in SF that can be used as a weapon, the falafel wrap is close to the top.  It's gigantic, and will cause serious damage if you get clocked with it(or eat too much of it).  Get everything on it with hot sauce.  While your conscience will tell you not to add the fried potatoes and eggplant, your evil twin has already confirmed to the wrap maker that you want them.  Don't worry about the guilt, the falafel wrap will soon divert all of the blood from your brain to your stomach.  Enjoy.
author: Frank S.

description: the falafel was on-point and pacified me during one of my worst hangovers in recent memory.
author: Marla W.

description:
good food and cheap.  two can easily split just about anything.  the hummus is good.  salads are nice - but the falafal is a little too deep fried and crunchy for my taste.
the place is a little dirty too.  i went to the bathroom to wash my hands and felt a little dirtier afterward.

however - i did like the food enough to go back.
author: adams w.

description: If you're big on authentic mediterranean, don't go here.  they load up your pita with lettuce, what's up with that?  people in the middle east don't even eat lettuce.
author: Dan Y.

description: i recently discovered the secretly cool seating area in the back. great for small groups who want to eat their falafel more intimately. i wouldn't say this is the freshest or most atmospheric restaurant i've ever been to, but it definitely has hit the spot repeatedly when i crave me some mediterranean deliciousness. in particular, their tabouleh is muy excelente. also, the owner, husein, is an incredibly generous supporter of local non-profits.
author: julia r.

description: one schwarma is more than enough to satisy a giant appetite - take part of it home! try the arabian coffee, it is fantastic. great little hide out too. they play middle eastern tapes all day long.
author: Applejack W.

description: Since 2 people can eat here for under $15, you get a star......this review is now a commentary on falafel's in San Francisco. I love fried food, but if you're going to indulge in the extra calories and fat grams it needs to be out of the fryer fresh. In NYC and Paris' Jewish Quarter I've eaten falafel that is the pinnacle of falafel-ness. They key to their tastiness is that they fry the falafel to order. The hot and crispy falafel balls contrast with cool tahini, crisp lettuce and creamy hummus to create something so simple, yet complex at the same time. In San Francisco, the cook a ton of falafel's ahead of time, nuke them then serve them in a wrap (which should really be a fresh pita)....all of the fat and calories of a made to order falafel, but not fresh from the fryer crunch and heat. Since falafels cook in under 3 minutes, they could be doing it right. It really is a shame, since SF street/etcnic food for the most part is terrific. They just cannot do falafel right....for falafel perfection, go to Mamoun's in NYC or New Haven, CT.
author: Matt H.

description: most of the things we ordered had a weird aftertaste or were so bland. the manager/owner was kinda surly, and to cap it off there was two huge trays of uncovered food in the back room, which was totally gross, never going back.
author: Jared Z.

description: they make an excellent falafel wrap...great too when paired with the extra spicy ginger ale.
author: dusty d.

description: This place has amazing food and large portions for cheap.I ate half of a falafel sandwich  for lunch and dinner ! I would recommend this place for anyone , its good for vegans and meat eaters alike.
author: Brittany L.

description: great falafel sandwich.  no onion and a little hot sauce.  huge!  3 stars b.c. haven't had anything else ...
author: Erika Y.

description: take this place for what it is or not at all. some people may love it for the cheap food. who can resist the falafel sandwich with that spicy tang and the fact that one wrap is really two meals. to eat the whole thing is to support the muffin top foundation... but do what you like. the decor leaves something to be desired so i'd rather order to go and head over to dolores park. this is not a place for someone expecting something fancy like the cheesecake factory. hahah. that place is such a piece of shit.
author: Faye P.

description: yeah, it's true, the big plastic bin where you're supposed to bus your used dishes is covered with food scraps, but who cares? order the falafel sandwich and shut up. it costs 5 bucks, is big enough for two (although i always eat a whole one and regret it), and it has eggplant and french fries inside. hello?
author: jean w.

description: This place is OK if you happen to be nearby, but it is not nearly as good as Old Jerusalem at Mission and 25th.  The shwerma are made with good quality meat and the fillings are nice, but the wrap always seem stale. The salads are decent if a little bland except for the green salad which is pathetic (where do they source pale white iceberg lettuce late in July?).  The pastry thing is a real dissapointment; dry crust, tough rice, and very little lamb. I find the decor very depressing.  So this place is probably 2 stars for eat in and 3 stars for take out.
author: Peter H.

description: My boyfriend and I order the falafel sandwich and split it. That and 2 sodas makes for a very filling $10 meal for two.
author: Happy M.

description: great food, decent prices, wish they would wash those pillows in the cave!!
author: M S.

description: my favorite falafel and shawerma joint in my hood...friendly staff...knows my name...and falafels are always fresh and crispy
author: Teresa H.

description: I've catered from here a few times and they are always prepared, well-priced, and organized. they're incredibly nice people who know how to make great food at the right price.
author: Sam H.
